description:
Damn best spare ribs ever. 

Now this is the epitome of hole-in-the-wall eats. It's a no frills, no nothing kinda establishment. But what attention isn't spent on the decor or customer service is spent on the taste of the food. It's one of those places even I don't like to sit and eat at but will buy their spare ribs just so we can eat it at home. They sell them frozen in Ziploc baggies too for you to steam up at home. No where else can you get this delicious flavor. 

Now I saw a review here on how there's no line or attentive service. Well that's the way it is man.  Have you not been to any of the most popular bakeries here like Napoleon/Na Po Lun 拿破仑? That's how we do it here in Chinatown. Now get yourself a back bone and get yourself some food. I'm getting hangry just thinking about it.
author: Lily F.

description:
Overall - food was tasty but wasn't great. The thing that caught my eye the most was the sanitation. As soon as we sat down, we noticed the table had black grime all over it. The auntie came to wipe it down a bit, but I wiped a second time with a napkin and it was disgustingly black. All the tables looked to be in similar conditions. Overall, I would not come back based on the sanitation alone - if the hall is this dirty, I don't want to imagine what the kitchen looks like.

Pros - relatively cheap (~$26 with tax to feed two hungry and hungover people and still have some leftovers), Siu Mai had a very strong and delicious pork flavor, Ha gao was tasty, and the chicken feet was good as well. The chicken in the lotus wrapped rice was a bit salty for my taste but the dishes here were a bit aggressive overall (neither good or bad).

Cons - sanitation was a huge no no. Definitely not coming back based on this alone.
author: Jaesung J.

description:
As everyone knows. Parking is almost impossible so take Uber guys!!

Cash only kinda place. You walking and there full with old Chinese folks I'm happy about this already. 

I only want to try shumai and shrimp crepes (white flat noodle wrap around shrimp and sweet sticky sauce on top) so I ordered those. Pork shumai is better than shrimp crepe that what I think. 

Cleaning is not their strong suit. I guess, they gave me a pair of chopstick and they are sticky AF (some people will call it gross but idk I just clean them up with napkin) 

Well overall this place got 3 stars from me. Will I be back? yes. But it gonna be take out more than sit and eat there. 

Ps. I might come by here in thanksgiving and buy some dimsum here if I host a party
author: Fah Z.

description:
A huge disappointment, one of my worst dim sum experiences in the world. I came to visit Chinatown with my family, and we expected there to be good Chinese restaurants for dim sum. I looked on Yelp and this was one of the few restaurants with a good rating, so we decided to come. We didn't want to fight crowds so we came for a later lunch, around 1pm.

We were immediately seated at a table directly at the entrance, where it was very windy because the door was kept open. We ordered several items quickly because we were hungry. I couldn't believe they actually served COLD dim sum to us. Not even warm at all. Including baked BBQ pork pastry (叉烧酥)! It was so bad we couldn't eat it. It might've tasted good if it was hot. A few other dishes were also cold but I don't remember which ones. The only one that was hot was 纸包鸡, which was wrapped in foil.

Overall, we were disappointed by SF's Chinatown and especially by this restaurant. We are a family that have lived in China, HK and Australia, and we definitely know what's good Chinese food. A restaurant that serves hot food cold is just disrespectful.
author: Monica K.

description:
Big mistake. Why did I even bother to eat dim sum here? 

Alright so I was visiting San Francisco and being the huge dim sum lover I am, I decided to try Chinatown's dim sum. I mean, it's freaking chinatown. Where else would I go for amazing dim sum other than getting it from the Chinese, right ?!??

So, I enter this establishment with my wife. Yuck. Dirty ass floor. Dirty ass tables. Sticky chairs. Chopsticks they gave us were still greasy and unsanitary. Gross right ?

Now the food. Hai gow and siu Mai. The two Staples. Ordered them both. Threw on some of that sate chili sauce and some soy sauce. They were both eh. I swear something I ate had msg all up in it. Maybe the sauce? No idea. But later that night, I did not feel well. Yes, the toilet bowl had a taste of what I had, and it sure wasn't pleasant. 

Food sucked. Place was dirty. Parking was expensive as heck. Not coming back. Rarely do I give 1 stars but man this place is 1 star or maybe even zero. Don't bother guys.
author: Dennis L.

description:
Any place that's cash only can only get 4 stars from me because that's just selfish. I ordered the fried shrimp dumplings and the shrimp and Chinese chives dumplings. Both of them were really delicious but definitely need some rice or vegetables to go with it. They are both very salty so it was kind of hard to finish both plates. It would probably have been better if I was sharing it with someone, as you are supposed to do with dim sum. 
The hours for this place suck but I guess it's meant to be a breakfast/lunch place even though I think I'd consider the food dinner food. 
Overall, the food was great and you should definitely try it
author: Angela L.

description: I love Dol Ho, I didn't know why I only put 3 stars before.  Over the years, I have bought dim sum to go, this is cheap dim sum we call it, rustic and not the fancy pretty plated ones you see at Yank Sing.  Nonetheless, it is absolutely delicious and with these kinds of cheap pricing, it makes me feel even better.  This the first place I had rice in metal jars, other spots have grown to add this item, but Dol Ho may be the first in chinatown and definitely the greasy durty best.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Summary: One of the best and cheapest dim sum places I have ever been to. Would recommend. We signaled to a woman that we wanted a table for 6. I think we got lucky with wait times because we waited less than 15 minutes.

Food 5/5 - Some of the best Dim sum I've ever tasted. Large portions, unlimited tea, with water and other beverages on request. We ordered items like pork and shrimp dumplings, chicken feet, turnip cakes, etc.

Price 5/5 - the price was $63 without tip and it was a group of 4 guys and 2 girls and we ordered a lot! 

Service 5/5 - Everyone was super prompt with service and we got a lucky seating right next to the kitchen. To pay the check all you have to do is walk up to the counter 

My only qualm is that the venue was a little cramped and old fashioned but there were so many pros about this place I did not include that into the rating. A little background, I have only had dim sum in the San Diego area and it's crazy expensive and less tasty.
author: Liangcheng R.

description:
Don't expect to be bedazzled with shiny cutlery and modern furniture. This is a local experience, and you will be surrounded by the Chinatown elderly - usually alone - getting their morning fix. 

* Spareribs over rice A++ : Plentiful and flavorful! First time seeing the over-rice version, which was served in a tin 
* Cha siu bao: Just ok, have had better elsewhere. Lacking meat 
* Fried tofu with shrimp: Scrumptious! 
* Shrimp rice roll: Thicker rice skin, which was VERY unique and delicious

Everything is $3-5. Can't beat that.
author: Vickie Z.

description:
I don't know what I was expecting when I walked in, but this was not it. My family and I came in and we were very confused about where to sit. The tables are communal and the place looks a bit dirty. 

We didn't know what they had to offer because we were never given a menu, so we just looked around us and asked for things from people pushing the carts. Speaking of carts, these were the most jankiest carts I've ever seen in my life. 

All of that aside, the food was pretty average, but on the good side of average. I would just order what you normally get at dimsum restaurants because they seem to have all of those. 

I don't think this would be a good place to go if you don't speak Chinese because I didn't hear an ounce of English in there. I'm not sure if I would recommend this place, but if you're looking for decent dimsum at a sit down restaurant and don't mind a little grime, this could be the place for you.
author: Alexis T.

description: Avoid this place! See pic. Pork buns had very little meat! I bought a dozen and 10 of the buns had barely any filling!
author: Peter A.

description:
I came to Chinatown wanting dim sum, and wanting something authentic. Oh boy did I get that at Dol Ho!  Firstly, they accept cash only, so come prepared. Secondly, I noticed that I was the only non-Chinese person in the small cafeteria-like space, and it seemed like most of the patrons were elderly folk. Finally when I requested a seat for myself, the lady working the counter quickly looked around; and at the first sight of someone barely ready to go, she quickly tried to shoo them out the door. I took these all as signs that I found what I was looking for haha. 

Apparently here they try and fit you wherever is open, so I was seated at a table with 5 other people. I've been to a couple dim sum places in Atlanta where the carts weave between tables and you pick what you want. I'm honestly still not sure how their syterm works here. I saw a cart come out with some food, and people swarmed it and pointed and picked what they wanted. Afterwards I was given a menu. 

Luckily another cart came came out with the pork and shrimp dumplings I wanted. I asked if she had shrimp toast. She didn't, but eventually she came out later just to bring me one. So I guess you can put in orders with any of the workers there. 

As for the food, I got the dumplings, shrimp toast, and a bowl of white rice. The dumplings were fantastic. The shrimp toast was pretty good, but not really crunchy/toasty how I like it. Rice was a little overdone. I would give this place 4.5 stars of I could. Truly an authentic experience with mostly delicious food. 

Also I wanted to take pictures of my shrimp toast, but after I took a picture of my dumplings, I could feel one of the grandma's across from me judge me (trust me, I know that look!) Being the dutiful Asian that I am, I didn't want to disappoint grandma again. So no pictures of shrimp toast :(.
author: Alfie B.

description:
Honestly, I only came here for the fried shrimp balls but there were many things that bothered me.

MAKE SURE TO WASH YOUR PLATE, CUP, & CHOPSTICKS WITH THE HOT TEA. Things are very dirty here.

Let's start with the positives: MUST GET FRIED SHRIMP BALLS. They're cooked and seasoned well. If you're a tourist and really want different, just get the fried shrimp balls. This is my only positive. 
___________________________________________________

NEGATIVES

(1) Poor Cleanliness. The waitress used a dirty, wet towel to wipe the old bones and food off table. She didn't bother making an effort to wipe it. IF YOUR FOOD FALLS ONTO THE TABLE, DO NOT EAT IT. 

(2) Poor Service. We ordered about 4 or 5 places of dim sum. It took a longer time for each dish to come. 

(3) CASH ONLY. Very inconvenient. I find it shady that businesses do cash only to avoid paying tax.
author: Mandy W.

description: Delicious things come in fours instead of threes!  Total fan of this place, hole in the wall but DELICIOUS!  Will go back!
author: Denni P.

description:
Came here and got a variety of dim sum. To be fair, we came here and a lot of things were gone like chicken feet, sticky rice, and some buns. However still tried a bunch of things like dumplings, spareribs, tofu.

All in all, nothing spectacular. I came here hungry, and left a little under content because I wasn't very motivated to eat the food. It's nice that you can sit down, but the food is just plain. It's like the minimal amount of flavor you need to make the dish pass. My favorite was actually the sesame balls. Probably won't come back again, better options for cheaper like good mon kok
author: Victor D.

description:
Cheap dim sum can be found, but not the best quality. I came in on a Friday morning around 9:45am, and they were busy but there was only a short line. They have a menu in English posted, so you can order from there or point at the items that you can see in the display case. I tried:

-Fried Meat Dumpling (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=nM-xmq-vJ7JZblmdkH9tPA&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Ok overall- Nice and crispy on the outside, and the filling had good flavors. However, the taro was very heavy and I was pretty full after only eating one. I probably wouldn't get this again.
-Shrimp Crepe ($4.00, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=3_r7cxpOszF1gFYaEjDcDQ&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): The rice crepe was surprisingly soft, but this roll has a lot of crepe versus shrimp. It was a good portion for the price, so I would get this again.
-Shiu Mai (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=pF0JrPRilz36kUlBbIx-Ng&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Pretty good, and this had good flavor. However, the pork was a little chewy.

I wouldn't go out of my way to come back here for dim sum, but would come back to pick up a couple items to go if in the area.
author: Amy D.

description:
Food was 2.5 stars. Service was 4 stars.

I came in and there was a good amount of people eating and waiting in line to order for take out. There wasn't much of a line and I felt like I was at a bar trying to order a drink. Chaos I tell you!

A bunch of older ladies cut in front of me, but the one lady who was running the show knew I was there first and saw I was lost and asked if it was to go or for here. 

She sat us down because we were going to eat there and we were promptly given a menu after she told the waitress we were eating there. I wanted to try an array of dishes. Prices were so good!

turnip cake
Definitely not what I expected. Texture was that of gelatin, more than a cake. Nice sear on the outside but it was room temp. Maybe because we got there 30 min before closing.

shrimp dumpling
Taste fishy, and not fresh

crepe with cilantro
It wasn't what I thought it was. I was expecting a flour egg crepe but it was a rice noodle with soy sauce dressing. It was actually pretty good but the noodle was a little over done

BBQ pork pastry and bun 
Definitely liked the bun better than the pastry. Maybe because the bun was nice and warm

well reviewed pork over rice
I was very disappointed in the one. The pork wasn't tender. It wasn't cooked long enough. The cartilage was still hard.  The sauce was thick and mushy. There was one rib that I ate that tasted rotten. As if the pork that was cooked wasn't fresh. Then while my bf tried one while he was poking around, there was a purple dot thing on one of the ribs. Maybe the pork wasn't fresh? I've never seen anything like it. I didn't have time to take a photo of it because I was turned off by it and the rotten rib I had tried.

I guess this is the type of fast food locals like to eat. I did come because of all the rave reviews. But I didn't feel like there was cook for quality. More for cook for the mass. 

They also aren't very keen on keeping the place tidy. We asked to get the chili sauce wiped off the table, and she just came to use a napkin to smear it around the whole table. 

The bowl the rib and rice came in was sticky on the outside like it hadn't been washed.....this place is very sketchy.....

It is a local place, it is cheap, and I don't mind giving those small shops a try. But I wouldn't be surprised to see a health inspector come by to say this place wasn't sanitary.....

I would shop around for other dim sum places as there are a ton in chinatown
author: Lynn C.

description:
If price were the primary concern, then Dol Ho would rate at least 3 Yelp stars. The prices are cheap here, but you get what you pay for. 

As for nuanced, balanced flavours and chefly technique & competence, you won't get it here. The dim sum at Dol Ho may be closer to home style cooking made without much finesse or sparkle by a favorite aunt who is culinarily challenged, but her heart is in the right place. 

Staff is friendly enough toward non Cantonese speakers although there will be some communication faux pas. Food may be closer to 2 Yelp stars, but I would like to give my favourite a one star up to 3- Yelp stars.  

Definitely for people who want quantity & rock bottom bargain basement prices. Whatever happened to such formerly excellent places such as Ton Kiang of the early 2,000's???
author: Gary I.

description: Excellent BBQ pork buns and sticky rice and chicken in leaves. Dumplings look good but as they all contain shrimp (which I'm allergic to), I had to skip them. We ordered 6 plates and the total was less than 25 dollars.
author: Vivienne T.

description:
CASH ONLY!!!!!!!!
I'm no dim sum connoisseur but I thought Dol Ho was pretty good given price and barely having to wait (I'm so used to loooooong lines for dim sum places in the Richmond district)! I liked the steamed bbq pork buns (which you order at the front rather than wait for a cart to come by) and the spare rib rice. Careful when you chew the spare rib rice! I chomped on a bone and my teeth felt weird all day. I came here with Chinese friends who did all the talking/ordering, and I would've been lost without them. Something that surprised me is that one of the servers just started putting 4-5 dishes on our table when we hadn't ordered anything... it's on you to tell them which ones you don't want so that they take it back.
author: Annie S.

description:
I love me some authentic, hole-in-the-wall feel type restaurants. If these old people are eating at this joint, and they don't speak english, you're in! LOL. Just my recommendation....don't come alone cus they'll stare at you and judge you for wanting to try like 10 things since you're not from this city. Yes, I was that one girl who had like 4 different dishes... I mean, it would have been like 8 different dishes but like I said, they were staring at me like "girl, why you alone and eating all that?" in my mind, I was thinking, " i aint' gonna eat this all. Can a tourist just taste what all the hype is?" LOL. Yeah, yeah. 
So for starters, DO try the spare ribs over rice. Tender, succulent spare ribs in their tasty black bean sauce over rice. Yes, it comes piping hot! Definitely enough for 2 people too. Next came the sui mai and the chicken feet. Soooo good of chicken feet. Definitely hella succulent and fall off the bone, melt in your mouth tender. Loved the flavors. The pork sui mai was okay--it reminded me of stinky pork, so that was kind of a turn off. But it had a decent taste to it. It definitely wasn't my favorite. The fried stuffed taro though... that was amazing! I loved how the filling had curry flavors in it and the taro itself was crunchy and had amazing textures. I loved this one the most!! Did not get to try the beef balls, but everyone was ordering that and the shrimp noodles.

They greet you, give you a menu, and you sit where you can fit! Food comes in different rushes, but they always remember your order. The chili oil is good (nothing different than other restaurants, in my opinion), so eat it with that. Otherwise, I had a good experience for the most part. I loved how authentic it felt. Hella cheap, and really fresh!!! Cash only! :)
author: Tan Lo S.

description:
Dol Ho is my absolute favorite place to get dim sum in San Francisco. This is the real deal: Everyone speaks in Cantonese, you will share a table with an old Chinese grandma/grandpa, the atmosphere is nonexistent, the wait staff does not wait on you, BUT you will leave having had some of the best dim sum in your life.

I grew up eating dim sum, and they have some dishes here I haven't even seen before. I don't even know the name of some dishes. The MANDATORY items: Steamed taro wrapped in vermicelli, spare ribs over rice, and the marinated chicken wrapped in aluminum foil (clearly don't know the names!!) 

It's cash only, so come prepared.
author: Denise L.

description:
My aunt told me there's nothing great to eat in chinatown and I had to prove her wrong! A party of 8 of us came to this little dim sum place and found this hole in the wall. It's definitely an old school dim sum place as all of its interior decor and furniture is super run down. But that's how you know it's legit! The best thing here is their chicken feet and rice noodles! Their rice noodles are definitely house made because it was so thin and soft! None of that super thick processed rice noodles you normally get at the fancy dim sum restaurants. We got 3 different types of rice noodles - cilantro, shrimp, and beef. The cilantro one was very refreshing and is perfect for my vegetarian friends. I usually don't like beef rice noodles but this was REALLY good. 

The reason why it got 4 stars is because the standard dim sum items such as Har gow and siu Mai was sub par. I wouldn't come here for those items as it doesn't seem too fresh.
author: Chi L.

description:
Unbelievable spare ribs over rice.  You. Must. Get. This.  All the locals do.  Big portion, gear price.  They serve the spare ribs over the rice so the oils and juices get into the rice.  A mazing.

The chili sauce they make in house is equally awesome. My go to in china town now
author: Joshua T.

description:
If you have an Anthony Bourdain sense of adventure, this place is worth a try. Dol Ho appears to be very authentic, set right in the heart of Chinatown.

Craving dim sum, me and my boyfriend ventured out on a Saturday morning.  Food is available to go or for dining there. We decided to wait for a table as it was fully packed.  It appears to be a local favorite, with many elderly patrons.

We weren't sure whether to order off the menu or wait for the girl with the steaming bowls of food to come by.  As we were deciding what we wanted, she came out with Crispy Shrimp Balls; Stuffed Bell Peppers; Shu Mai; regular Shrimp Balls; and Paper (actually foil) Wrapped Chicken. I couldn't get the foil off the chicken to eat it, so I skipped that and ate the other items, which were delicious. A steaming pot of black tea was served to us without asking, very welcoming on a chilly December morning.

The atmosphere here is very casual and basic.  Tables are very close together. Various guests would wander back and forth from the kitchen, making the restaurant feel like a real neighborhood hang.

By the time we left, we were stuffed. For five small plates filled with food and tea for two people, the bill came to just under $20.  It is cash only here, so come prepared. Tips are collected and stored in a large steel pot for sharing amongst the restaurant staff.

While I'm not sure whether I would go back, dining here was a very interesting experience, and a very authentic taste of Chinatown.
author: Lynda T.

description:
Authentic place for dim sum and apparently a favorite for locals. We tried
1. bbq pork bun: the buns are very sweet
2. Custard buns: same as above
3. Spare ribs: everyone loves it
4. Sticky rice with chicken: it came with two portions
5. Chicken feet: great!
6. Salty dumplings: very good! On the sweet side as well
7. Tofu with shrimp: average

Everything tastes good and the service was great as well. I will highly recommend this place.
author: Sunny X.

description: Food was very tasty.  We got so much dim sum here and it was so cheap too.  We got the hagou, shrimp paste in pepper, shrimp paste in eggplant (not as tasty), deep fried fish ball, and some other stuff that I can't remember.  It was all very very tasty.  However, I quickly lost my appetite when I found a curly thick hair embedded in the deep fried fish ball.  I dare not to think where that hair came from... yuck.  How gross.
author: Grace W.

description:
We were staying in SF Chinatown and were in the mood for some HK style cart dim sum. I've tried carryout dim sum from Good Mong Kok Bakery the last time I was in SF and wanted to find a place where we could sit down for once. Came here after reading the recommendations on yelp and was unfortunately very disappointed.

This place is very popular with the locals and it seemed as though their specialty item is the "pai guat fan" which translates to steamed pork ribs over rice. Didn't get a chance to try this but it comes in a metal pot and is doused in some sweet soy sauce.

Beef steamed rice rolls - ok
Beef meatballs - same meat as the stuff they put in the rice rolls. Would prefer to get it with the rice rolls to balance out the saltines
Har gow (shrimp dumplings) - way too small, not enough flavor, and doughy sticky wrapper
Shiu Mai - chunky greasy pieces of pork gristle, not my favorite
Egg custard bun - large chinese sweet bun with egg yolk custard. Was ok.

I can't help but use the word "okay" throughout this review because nothing stood out. It was relatively cheap, nothing impressive.
author: Alvin S.

description:
My husband and I are new to the Bay Area and wanted to give this place a try for dim-sum. This place is one of the most authentic dim-sum places we have ever been. 

You walk into the restaurant and wait in a line. (People occasionally cut the line to order dim-sum to go.) No one is there to seat you, you basically wait until seats open up. A gentlemen behind me pointed us in the direction of two empty seats. We shared a table someone else, it seemed to be that many people shared a table. 

There were no menus just a woman who would bring out a cart with different food selections. Because the tables were so close she would make her way through and would ask what we wanted from the cart. Once she gave us the food she would make a tally mark on our order sheet that was left on our table. The gentlemen we shared the table
With was very kind, he must have told one of the waitresses that we wanted water because she cane back with two glasses and a water pot! We were doing fine with the house Tea but had some water since he so kindly asked. After our meal we thanked him for sharing the table and he simply smiled and waved.

Tips:
It's cash only
Be patient because the food comes out in waves
Be ready to get cozy and make new friends
Go with the flow and enjoy
You can get some pastries to go at the front!

Next time we will most likely take our dim sum to go, the food was delicious and well priced! We had about 6 items from the menu (shrimp dumpling, shrimp roll, shrimp/fish ball on green pepper, shrimp ball, beef balls, and pork with rice) all for $24.
author: Kim D.

description:
Would really give no stars if it was an option. My 3 friends and I waiting a long 20 minutes just to get our own seats. There is NO customer service at all. There were no organization or "real line". The line to order "to go" and "dine in" were mushed together. The people behind us were getting seats before us, so we decided to sit ourselves as soon as customers paid & left. We sat for another 10 minutes while customers around us were getting food and tables got waited. Our table was messy from the previous customers and they paid no attention to the mess or us. No one greeted us or asked if we wanted anything to drink or better yet, offered to clean the mess. The lady with the cart never made it past the first two tables by the exit from the kitchen anyways. After sitting for awhile we decided to leave. 

We did not get to experience the customer service nor the amazing food other Yelpers were raving about. However, I found a better place down the street for similar pricing and better organization and customer service. I will not be giving this place another chance. Go to Great Eastern Restaurant instead y'all.
author: Brenda V.

description: Delicious food, but questionable service. Typical of small, local Chinatown eateries like this, but service was so slow for us and it'll probably be a little more difficult for those who don't speak Chinese (but not impossible). The food itself was pretty good though, one of the yummier dim sum places I've tried!
author: YL L.

description:
If you're prissy, the kind that wants to be treated like kings and queens, stop reading! This place is not for you. If you're cool and just want good tasting food, proceed!

Super good, Cheap, and Authentic Dimsums. So authentic, you'll think you're in Hongkong or mainland china because you really can't rely on a good service or clean place. If you need or want something, ask! They won't offer anything. Lol. But food wise, everything taste good. I love the Shu Mai, Spareribs, and Ha Kaw the best! Love the sesame bun too but they run out of these fast!

For the price, We had 10 dimsum orders, 2 rice meals and 3 soda. All for about $40+
Best time to go is after the lunch time craze. Or else you'll have to wait and find a table on your own. 
Oh and good luck with parking! We always do garage parking on the street before Dol Ho.
author: Anne D.

description:
Came here after 12 on a Saturday afternoon for dim sum - it was packed so we had to wait a little bit for a table. Ended up at a shared table with two other people. It's a hole in the wall - lots of Chinatown locals and it's the type of shop where you can eat in or order to go.  Place seats about 30 people. 

Service is definitely lacking - workers barely made eye contact with us. We semi sat ourselves - this nice old lady customer told us to come take her table as she was getting ready to leave. We lingered there wondering if it was ok to take the table and we just sat down since no one really acknowledged us. 

Ordering also took a long time - again, the lone cart lady barely made her way to us and it was hard to flag anyone down as eye contact was avoided. Once we did get help, had no idea what the lady was saying. I still don't know if we are supposed to order from the menu or take what we could from the cart. 

Once we finally got food.... Portion size was great. Quality ranges from so-so to decent. Some dishes were room temperature which I didn't fancy too much. Pricing is about $3/$4 plate (mostly $3). 

Overall, this place offers large portions and is budget friendly. Unfortunately, the lack of service plus the mediocre food cancels that out. I don't feel compelled to come back again.
author: Laura C.

description:
We stopped by the other day in the morning and it was packed with old Chinese people.

Only non-Chinese speakers were us... LOL

Literally, there is no parking. Streets are all packed and so much construction going on.
We found a parking garage one block south from this place. It was $3 per 30 minutes.

You will be sharing your table with other customers which is common in SF Asian restaurants.

Their menu is very concise. $3.25-4.25, very reasonable.
4 dumplings come on 1 plate.

The way they call is different from how I know, so they call the shrimp look fun "crepe" instead.

I had to ask the waitress to find out.

Anyways, we ordered most basic dimsums: shrimp dumplings, shrimp and chive, fried shrimp ball, stuffed eggplant, and shrimp crepe.

The taste was ok. Not great. 
I have had better dimsums.

Some came kinda cold. They were serving plates that were sitting around instead of just cooked ones.

Hence, I give 3 stars.
author: Toshie L.

description:
While my friend and I were visiting SF, she wanted to try out the dim sum there to see if it's any better than NYC. Short answer: DEFINITELY not.

Long answer:
We were looking for a sit down place and Dol Ho had some really great reviews. So we went in on a Monday at around 10 in the morning and we to one of the last tables. Looking around, there were quite a few older Chinese people, so we assumed the food would be good and not a tourist trap. Sadly, we were mistaken. Everything we tried (shrimp churng fun, shrimp dumplings, chicken feet, shumai) were all just mediocre. The only thing that I actually liked was the meatballs. Their chili oil definitely made everything else better tasting so I ended up smothering everything in that.

Service is pretty much what you would expect at a Chinese restaurant. Only, it does take a while to get your food, unlike the cart-pushing places in NYC. They don't have carts of dim sum here. Somebody will come and take your order of the dim sum you want.

Maybe next time, I'll just try one of those 'to-go' dim sum places.
author: Mel T.

description:
I dont comment much but for this spot i have to. Dol ho is definitely the best dim sum spot in san francisco. Service is a lil weird but you'll get over it. 

Recommendations are;
- beef crepe 
- shrimp toast 
- BBQ pork pastry (my sister's to die for item)
- steamed pork ribs over rice 
- pork and salty fish over rice

Over and out.
author: Mu C.

description: Can you hang with the locals? Not intimidated  or frustrated not being able to speak and understand Chinese, but you can read a menu in English, then you're good to go. Just point at the menu and the waitress will know what you want without even writing anything down. Most things are made to order and brought out to your table steaming hot. Everything was tasty and I would definitely return.
author: Gary W.

description:
Do come for the spare ribs over rice (to go version). That's it. 

Overall food quality is barely ok. You can expect dirty food crumbs on your plates. Dishes are either $3 or $4. Service is minimal. 

Do yourself a favor. If you're going to have sit down dim sum, go elsewhere. If you're only craving spare ribs over rice, then come here.
author: Dana Z.

description:
Talk about a hole in the wall. You have to come here with a local who's not afraid to vocalize their wants and needs, preferably in Mandarin.  My dad took us here on a recent visit because the line at The Great Eastern was way too long.  

This place serves up authentic dim sum and communal tables.  We waited about 5 mins before seeing a group of 4 get up so of course we pounced over there hovering while the other patrons were still gathering their belongings.

Once seated tea and table settings are quickly produced and then the waiting game. We sat fairly close to the kitchen so we were able to wave down the one lady with the carts as soon as she stepped outside of the kitchen. There was only one cart at a time in the dinning room but it looked like she made quick work of the rounds.

The servers speak extremely limited English.  The dim sum was delicious if not somewhat standard. I don't think they had juicy dumplings. Skip the restrooms. 

3.5 stars for the authentic Chinatown experience.
author: Han D.

description:
Dol Ho is a wonderful little restaurant in the heart of San Francisco Chinatown that serves up the basics of traditional dim sum!

I came here with a group of four on a Sunday for a nice dim sum lunch. We were able to get a table promptly though the place was quite packed. It seemed like a lot of people come here for take-out though. Dol Ho is not your clean, modern style dim sum spot, but more so a simple, dirty, and traditional place very fitting of the Chinatown area. This gives the place its own charm in a way. The dim sum here is all very good and I found myself enjoying every bite very much. I typically am not a huge fan of the meatballs at dim sum restaurants, but I found the ones here to be exceptionally good. One other item I found interestingly good is their mini rice bowls which come with various items such as pork spareribs and chinese sausage. They come with a sweet soy sauce which mix in with the rice very well.
author: Joshua M.

description:
I was always skeptical about this place but my fiancé always has a way of converting me & making me a believer.

This place is a hole in the wall like everyone else has stated. I do wish they'd clean up a little bit more but it is what it is, there's no frills and thrills here, only good & cheap food!

Don't expect good attentive service here, you're lucky if you get a greet. Majority of the time, you are expected to come in, find a table and seat yourself. Don't expect to have the whole table by yourself because someone will always be joining you in the empty seat next to you, it's the whole Asian communal table way aka "dop toy", which translates to stacking tables, which really isn't that bad. I love watching and studying how other people adapt to this place, their ordering style, what they order, what do they do while they wait, etc. Trust me, the OGs that come here are some of the most interesting folks you can watch & study! 

If you're a noob to this place or not the regulars, the server come over and ask you what kind of tea and what food you'd like. The OGs aka the old grandparents that come here often actually just get up and make their own tea and servers have memorized what their regulars order. 

For the two of us, we would usually only spend under $20 on dim sum here, which is a steal, considering that we've racked up $100 tabs elsewhere. My absolute go to is the spareribs rice, it's freaken amazing! They have the most flavorful spareribs I've ever had and they've mastered the rice and soy sauce. It's comfort food for me, it really brings back childhood memories of my mom always bringing my sister and I sparerib rice plates after school.

Try a bit of everything here, it's all good food and it's very friendly on the wallet.
author: Kelly L.

description:
MY husband and I were looking for authentic dim sum.  We found it here.  Small hole in the wall place gets busy in the morning.  Communal seating is here. The servers here are dominantly Chinese speaking.  Luckily, they had a small menu of what you can order.

The food is good and the real deal.  All so tasty and legit.

Gotta stop by when you're in the mood for good Chinese food.
author: Lisa L.

description: CASH ONLY!!! This dirty hole in the wall dim sum shop is really good. The steamed items are fresh and at least the items we tasted were good. The best item IMO is the salty fish with pork patty over rice. It's a very asian dish so you should probably already enjoy eating salty fish before ordering this.  Also, don't expect much in terms of service. This place caters to the locals and if you want something you go and get a wait staff and tell them what yo bring you. It may be a little difficult for people who do not speak Chinese to eat here.
author: F H.

description: Great service, even for our party of NINE.  It was a nice dim sum experience and very affordable.  Fed nine people full for $80 with tip!  The food was good but not great.
author: Katie P.

description: It's a small, definitely no fuss place, but we thoroughly enjoyed our dim sum meal with lots of delicious shrimp and pork options. Great foil wrapped chicken. We ate well and the total cost was under $10 a person. Will definitely return!
author: Colleen D.

description: Best Dim Sum I've had for its price. Better than some restaurants. We keep coming back. Pork ribs with preserved black beans are a must. Their char siew paos and puffs are the best I've had at this price point. In all $23 for all this food. The shrimp used are large, sweet and juicy.
author: Wei Lin N.

description: This is a locals spot that specializes in steamed spareribs and rice ($4.25). Everyone gets it to go or if you want to fight 89 year old Chinese ladies, be my guest. As a Chinese person, the food is decent, but not for the faint of heart if you don't know what you're doing.
author: David S.

description: Cheap. Poor service. Decent dim sum, but not a large variety. It's always filled with Asians, so you know it's authentic. Caveat emptor, unless you order in Cantonese. If you don't, expect to order by pointing and gesturing at the cart they roll around every five to ten minutes.
author: Yves L.

description:
Yes yes yes!!! The real deal is here. They do not speak much English But they will understand you. 

Food Great. Wow the best and original dishes ever. 
Service Super. All the servers are so sweet and nice. 
Price super! 
Location wow!

Please visit this please you will love it. 
Only cash!
author: Cris B.

description: Shrimp chive dumplings were the best thing on their menu I think. The environment was full of loud, Chinese folks.
author: Kissy F.

description:
I didn't have enough time on this last trip to contrast multiple dim sum places, but I want disappointed with this one. It was pretty much what I was expecting: loud, busy, chaotic, not terribly clean, not particularly focused on customer service as many Americans have come to expect it, but tasty and relatively authentic culturally.

The other folks who were with me....uh, maybe it was a little more authentic than they'd expected. Tough cookies, kiddos...eat up!
author: B. C.

description: After going to a nicer, expensive dim sum restaurant in SF, I was eager to check out the opposite side of the spectrum. Dol Ho is a gritty hole in the wall in Chinatown, packed with locals. I ordered three dishes to go: steamed hum bao, har gao, and short ribs over rice. Each cost ~40% what I spent at the other place, though with a bit of a dip in quality. The short ribs were questionable, but the har gao and hum bao were perfectly serviceable. I'd love to come back and power-eat my way through the menu on the cheap with some friends
author: Abdullah A.

description: Cheap, fresh, tasty. Not a fancy place, mostly populated by Chinese regulars chatting away and reading the newspaper.  You sit at communal tables but don't expect too much chit chat from them if you are an outsider. We had shrimp flat noodle, har gow, chimp chives dumpling, and shrimp crispy ball, and shark fin dumpling -- bill was $23!
author: Mary K.

description:
DANG! This place is the real deal. I suggest you come in with a group of four or more so you can try more. It was just two of us and we filled up too fast. 

It was packed on our visit. We were the only white people there and clearly novices. The conscientious server brought us hot tea and a plate of delicious pork pot stickers to get us started...figuring, I'm sure, that everyone likes pot stickers.. and of course we do and did. Next came the cart and we picked out the fried shrimp balls and the stuffed eggplant. Both were amazing, but each plate had four servings, two more than we needed. Next we ordered the steamed beef crepes and the pork buns. The crepes were lovely on the plate in a small pool of soy/brothy goodness. As for the buns, we've had versions of these that we preferred at other restaurants, we thought the filling to bun ratio was off.  We left too much food behind, we probably had enough for four people to eat and the total for our meal was under $20.  Such a deal.
author: Diana D.

description:
Service was horrible. We were seated all the way inside a longer table with other people sharing the table, an older Chinese couple sitting next to us, sharing the table saw how even when we try to get the staff's attention to order everyone ignored us, they kindly got up and informed a staff member for us that we need to order. 

When the staff came to take our order, she kept telling us literally everything we tried to order that they are out of it. We tried asking her what are we able to order? She then just talked to us in Chinese although we do not speak Chinese. We kept seeing the food she claims they are out being served to people in the restaurant, and when we asked how come they get the food, she just said "last one", assuming she's saying those are the last orders available for those dishes. 

At any rate, as we already wasted 40 min just trying have someone take order just to be told we can't order anything because everything is "out". We just left the place to grabbed dimsum at another place nearby in which the food was great and staff were kind and welcoming.
author: Jihye J.

description: We came in for a quick snack Monday afternoon. The waitress barely said three words, threw a menu at us and literally piled plates/silverware/cups/tea/chopsticks/napkins on our table and was a bit rude in doing so. The menu is small so we ordered two dumplings and the bbq pork buns. The pork dumpling wasn't good, my fiance said the shrimp & chive dumpling was tasty and the bbq pork buns were good as well. Everything came out right away so that was nice.
author: Terah R.

description:
Their dim sums are great!! I love their shrimp meat ball, so amazing! I think they ground the shrimp meat and then deep fried it. OMG, first time in my life having something like this. It's crunchy outside and so soft, so juicy inside. I would give this item a 10 stars review if I could. 

However, you do need to bear in my that the restaurant itself looks pretty low end. If you need to eat in a nice environment, this is probably not something for you.
author: Christian W.

description: This place was packed with their regular customers who were mainly an older generation of Chinese people. Tables are shared with other parties. The regulars were seen going to the kitchen and getting their own tea & cups. The popular dish there was the spare ribs over rice for $4. The chicken combination roll was the best thing we had. Fried stuffed tofu had no flavor.
author: LC M.

description:
This is Po Po and Gong Gong's playground. All of Chinatown's elder folks come here and rule this joint. We were waiting for a table and next in line. A table opens up, and I'm hesitant on whether I should seat myself. Two g-mas barrel over me and take the seats for themselves. Dannnng son, no mercy for outsiders. 

I came here because of their sparerib with rice combo. For $3.75, it did the trick. All the other dim sum is really cheap- around $2.50 a dish, say whaaa. Their daikon cake was a bit too thick for my liking though. 

Two Tips:
- Peak hour is 12-1pm on weekdays. Chinese elderly are VERY regulated on when they eat (my Gong Gong is living proof). So, it will be very crowded then. Come around 11am or after 1:15pm to miss the crowd. 
- Service is VERY slow during peak hour. One person rolls out the cart and moves around very slowly. So slow that people from other tables get up, walk to the cart, and grab dishes for themselves. 

Come here for a unique cultural experience. Dim sum hole in the wall, chyeeaaah.
author: Joanna L.

description: It's kinda ironic I grew up across this place and my family never ate there. But back in the day there were more dim sum places and as with passage of time  there are only a couple left. But about 5 years ago my mom started going there to get their dim sum and it's not bad. Sometimes a bit too salty I guess depending who's making it. I love their haw gar, beef noodle crepe & law may guy (sticky rice with chicken & mushroom not the chinese tamale) It's a tiny place I never eat in b/c my Mom's place is near by. It's pretty cool to walk across & get a bunch of dim sum to take back & enjoy with the family whenever I'm visiting my Mom every week.
author: Jo K.

description:
4 stars for food but 2 stars for service.

Came here on Saturday as a group of five having never dined in a Chinatown restaurant before. The moment we stepped in, it was chaotic. Tons of people standing around for the take out counter with no sense of order or a line. We stood around hoping to be seated only to realize that it's a first come first serve communal type set-up.

We finally managed to grab a table but had to wait for it to be cleared and waited even longer for any food carts to come out. Any questions asked and you'd get barked back at by the staff. If you have to use the bathroom, hold it. You have to walk through the kitchen to get to the disgusting bathrooms and back out. It's better you save yourself from finding out what the conditions are like back there. Ignorance is bliss, right? The longer we sat there, the more unsanitary it seemed.

The food is decent...comparable to other dim sum joints I've been to in the past. The only thing that really stood out was the shrimp dumpling. If you want anything specific, order via the staff and they'll place an off the cart order for you.

Prices are really reasonable. We ordered about 10-11 dishes and it was ~$33. 

Based on the overall experience, I probably won't be back.
author: Claudia C.

description: Cash only ! Foreigners welcome but may be put off by non English speaking workers . Most of the clientele are age 60+ OG Cantonese geriatrics who sit around read the paper, drink tea and chit chat to each other for 6 hours . Because of that a table is hard to snag (even with communal style seating) . It took me three tries to finally see the restaurant not packed full.. I came before 10 on a Monday morning . I didn't have enough cash to try a lot of their dishes but many ppl were getting their spare ribs with rice. Their prices are very reasonable compared to other dim sum restaurants and they give large portions . Just don't be shy and tell the workers what item you want they have a menu in English . But you need to be familiar with what dim sum items you like as there are no push carts nor pictures . It's definitely a hole in the wall place so don't expect to get catered to the workers probably will not even acknowledge you when you come in .. you're supposed to seat yourself . Out of all the dim sum places I tried I liked this one the most .
author: Thang S.

description: Soooo good! We had a TON of dim sum. I've had good Dim Sum before, but this is by far the absolute best! Their fried taro had a beautiful depth and umami to it that I have never tasted in other restaurants. Also, the staff was very friendly and helpful. Small place, though, so get there a little early, and leave yourself time to stop by some of the awesome markets nearby.
author: Amy R.

description: Came here as a backup due to my normal spot being closed. The food was pretty good, nothing special. Food came out very fast and the waitress was nice, although no one really speaks English. Overall not a bad experience.
author: Bryson G.

description: A no muss, no fuss eatery at proverty prices.  This is a real old school Chinatown place to fully appreciate the local scene.
author: Dennis Y.

description: Felt like an authentic Chinatown experience. The restaurant isn't upscale, so if that's your thing, you will be disappointed. Instead, this seems like a place the locals hang out... we were the only non-Chinese speakers there at the time.  We tried a few different dishes. Loved the dumplings and spring rolls. And our family of 5 ordered a lot, but I surprised the bill came to only $32! Amazing value.
author: Brian B.

description: My grandma always takes me here. This is some good dim sum lol. And it's always fun sitting next to Chinese grandmas.
author: Christopher L.

description: Been here a few times......one of only a few dim sum places open early. We have always been the only gringos in the place and the food has always been good. Cheap, too.
author: Arom A.

description: Besides great dim sum, this shop has excellent steamed bun products. I am especially fond of their mantou. Whenever I am in Chinatown, I buy half a dozen (cold) or more to-go to devour in my leisure at home/work. Just zap in the microwave for 40 seconds, spread with peanut butter. Try it. Have a great day!
author: Landlubber L.

description: They have the best dim sum!!! Everything is done fresh and. Their shrimp fried ball is the best!! It always fresh off and tast good! They are normally pack do it is best to go early to grab yourself a table to sit at. Nice people who work there and they give good recommendations if it Your 1dt time there!
author: Calvin T.

description:
One of the best foodie adventures I had during my stay in SF! We were staying near Chinatown and decided on dim sum for a late lunch. Luckily, Dol Ho was open till 3pm! 

This is one of those hole-in-the-wall's you hear of that lacks cleanliness but has excellent food. Every one is a local, they walk in, grab their own dishware and tea and find their own seating. So if you're coming in, better grab seating before someone else does! 

What made this experience so fun was the ordering process. You can order specific dishes but most of the time, whatever they decide to make in the back, they bring out on the wheel cart. You take it or you don't. It's kind of a chef's choice style, it's a little slow but makes it an adventure! Otherwise, you can order what you want from the one lady server. 

What we ordered and liked:
Siu mai - so meaty! 
Ha gow - wrapping is so fresh
Ha gow with shrimp and chives - must get
Shrimp ball with fried tofu
Spare ribs over rice - fell right off the bone

We also ordered steamed buns to go, which weren't bad and were quite cheap! Our tab was less than 30$ for 3 people. This was a cool experience to get away from touristy restaurants and get to eat with the locals. They speak canto, mandarin and some English. I always do the point and numbers thing with my fingers, and it works without fail! Must try if you're visiting SF and you're looking for some authentic dim sum.
author: Joanna H.

description: Dim sum was sooo good here! As well as the spareribs with rice. It was a long wait though until we were finally seated, but as soon as three seats opened up we were seated. My friends and I sat on a table with other people, but we didn't mind. Basically if you fit there, you sit there lol.
author: Kira Lynn M.

description:
Dol Ho's beef ball and black bean spareribs is the best in SF. This place is lit and a diamond in the rough. I'm a hole in the wall kind of guy and I love this inexpensive and large portion servings.

Black Tiger will not lead you astray. Come and feast.
author: Teason M.

description:
The best spare rib over rice dim sum dish you can get!

This restaurant is open early to local Chinese uncles and aunties who want a cheap, delicious bite while reading the morning Chinese paper. In the morning, it is seat yourself, communally, at any of the small tables. You have to order with the 2 waitresses/cashier. The language barrier was an issue, but between my sixth grade level Mandarin and my boyfriend's third grade level Cantonese, we managed to order a few of our dim sum favorites. 

As mentioned above, definitely get the spare rib over rice. They are generous with the spare ribs and the sauce that seeps onto the white rice is fantastic. The daikon cakes are also delicious!
author: Swan L.

description:
If you want to experience traditional cantonese dim sum (food and atmosphere).  This is the best place in chinatown, if not all of San Francisco. For the unfamiliar, you share tables with strangers, similar to cafeteria style. I personally prefer the spareribs over rib. It has a very good balance in the fermented beans with the seasoning. The rice itself is special.  This place is one of the few places left where they steam their rice compare to just boiling it. This creates a delightful texture in the rice where its fluffy but also not mushy. 
Another must try item is the beef balls. They are so tender but also bounce, which is a must for beef balls. Not too much fillers mean you get your worth of beef. As with the spareribs, they are perfectly seasoned. If beef is not your thing. The deep fried shrimp balls are a good substitute. 

Overall. If you want good cheap cantonese dim sum dol ho is great choice with an experience that anyone's grandparents will call legit
author: jed x.

description:
Quite possibly the best "humble" dim sum in all of San Francisco. By "humble", I mean the old tea-house type of dim sum where you have chopsticks in a canister in the center of the table and the prices are low while the conversations loud as opposed to the Yank Sing variant of dim sum which includes white table clothes and is fit for a business lunch. It's mainly frequented by the local elderly Chinese which is great because if anyone knows good dim sum and a whale of a deal, they sure do. It is also very useful to have some working knowledge of Cantonese to communicate here--you ask the waiter pushing the cart around for what you want or else point to what's on the cart, but it's very useful to be able to ask. The service is brisk and can seem a tad bit rude at times, but this is not uncommon for this type of restaurant.

The stand-out dishes tend to be the fun guo, har gow, shaomai, and steamed ribs. The turnip cake normally is ok, too. Like many dim sum shops, if something was made earlier in the day it may be cold or rubbery or lumpy. It's not possible with so small a kitchen and the way they operate to keep everything piping hot and seemingly fresh like Yank Sing can do, however never have I ever had anything I suspected was spoiled here, either. I agree with other reviewers the place could be cleaner, but it doesn't seem unsanitary and again, the prices are so low you feel in some sense you're getting what you pay for--the food portions are quite generous, so if the place could use some cleaning and even redecorating maybe, so what?

I would certainly recommend Dol Ho for 1) good and authentic dim sum at very fair prices and 2) a glimpse of how Chinatown remains today--not fully touristy but very much an immigrant enclave.
author: Mike W.

description:
You know a dimsum place is legit when it looks pretty janky. When I walked in, I definitely got the impression that I have been to an identical restaurant in China with the exact same layout. It's not the cleanest or the best service I've had for dimsum but the food was amazing. 

Some of my favorites were definitely: spare ribs over rice (the sauce is super tasty), har gow, and the pork bun. If you're looking for something a little bit lighter, don't go for the fried shrimp dishes because they were on the greasy side. 

We got A LOT of food and it turned out to be $11 a person and that's after tip! Definitely can see myself coming back.
author: Cassie Z.

description:
What an experience coming here. The service is completely lacking but you really can't beat the cheap price for this delicious food. It came out to just $7 each person including tax and tip! Reminder that it is cash only. I recommend coming here in a small group. It took us half an hour to snag a table for 4 at a peak hour but there were plenty of seats for 2 people that share a table with another group.

The service was so inattentive of us it was almost entertaining to try to handle everything ourselves. The server doesn't help you get a seat so it's a free for all hovering over the tables that look like they're about to finish their meal. When we finally got a table we had been sitting without a server come to us for so long my friend went into the kitchen to grab plates and chopsticks for us and I walked up to the only cart across the room and picked out my dim sum.

Highly recommend the spareribs over rice. It lives up to the hype. Super cheap for the serving size and is so tender. The other classic dim sum items like shumai, shrimp dumplings, and shrimp rice noodle rolls were all great. You should order off the menu if there's something you really want because there's only one cart that comes around at a time and it might not bring what you are hoping for.
author: Linda X.

description:
On a recent "Tour de Dim Sum To Go" in the Stockton/Jackson/Pacific Street area, this obscure place ended up being the best of the bunch.  Yes, the service was a bit abrupt and it helps if you can speak some Chinese, but their dim sum delivered!
The har gow, siu mai, shrimp & chive dumpling, and sticky rice in bamboo leaves all received high praise and top marks - especially from my daughter who is a bona fide dim sum connoisseur.  Also impressive were their hom sui gok (fried dumpling made w sticky rice flour) - which maintained a nice crispy interior and had delicious filling with the proper thickness of the shell.

This place is a keeper.
author: Lewis C.

description: Visiting SF over the weekend from OC. Was nursing a hangover on Sunday morning and had a sudden craving for dim sum. Found this spot on yelp and decided to take a walk to order some takeout. Ended up with 4 items: turnip cake, shrimp dumplings, chive and shrimp dumplings and the fried Mochi (meat fillings on the inside). Everything tasted authentic and better than any spot in SoCal. Price came out to be a whopping $11.50. I have a feeling I'll be craving this place for some time to come.
author: Jesse L.

description:
I haven't ate at this place in over 15 years but I still remember their steamed rice with spareribs. DROOOOOOL! I always crave it but I'm hardly ever in San Francisco and I don't know it's location.. Until recently. My mom wanted to check out the Asian Art Museum for their Taiwanese exhibit so she asked me where I wanted to eat afterwards. I asked if she remembers the dim sum place with the spareribs over rice and she told me to look it up on Yelp. 

Still as tasty as I remember! We ordered some other dishes like shao mai, shrimp dumplings, chicken feet, rice roll with shrimp, taro cake, etc. We had about 10 dishes including the 2 rice with spareribs to go and the bill was about $35! SO cheap! 

Ok the cons.
1. Hole in the wall type of place so don't expect to wine and dine.
2. Not so great customer service. There's no one really there to seat you so if you see an open table, run over and claim it!
3. There's only 1 lady pushing the cart (she does not look happy) so you have to get her attention before everyone else or else no food for you. 
4. Cleanliness is questionable.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Hole in the wall sit-down dim sum place. This is not a fancy place with lots of large tables for big parties. It's quite small, and I only saw one dim sum cart moving around the place. If you're a small group, be prepared to end up sitting at a shared table with other small parties. If you're a large group, be prepared never to get seating during peak hours. Made the mistake of coming at noon on a Friday, and we were never able to get seated and ended up getting food to-go.

Shrimp dumpling (har gow)- good
Shrimp dumpling with Chinese parsley- note that the parsley is pretty much cilantro. This is not the same as shrimp dumplings with chives.
Pork dumpling (shu mai)- good
Pork and vegetable bun- too much bun, not enough filling
BBQ pork bun- too much bun, not enough filling. BBQ pork is more on the sweet side.
Sesame ball (dessert)- filled with mung bean not red bean

An order of the dumplings or small dishes is about 4 pieces for $2.75. We were able to eat for about $10pp. Far from great dim sum, but it's cheap and fast.

CASH ONLY (of course).
author: Alice T.

description: Delicious and a great experience! Dumplings were perfect. Friendly and welcoming and so inexpensive. So glad to find this for lunch today!
author: Laura M.

description: The food was cheap and delicious. Definitely got the job done. A no thrills restaurant, definitely lacking in professionalism as they start handing you plates of food without asking.
author: Brian N.

description:
I usually don't give five stars but this place will be a place I will forever frequent when I'm in the area. It's a small little joint only patronized by locals. Tourists usually just get something to go at the counter.  If you're expecting top notch service do not come here. If you're willing to step in the kitchen real quick and pour yourself some tea, then this is the place for you. 

The food is spectacular. HUGE portions for half the price of typical dim sum in Chinatown. They literally have to cut your pieces of dim sum in half with scissors because it's so gargantuan. One of the few places left that cart out their dim sum. Fresh, fresh, fresh is all I can say. 

Get the spareribs over rice. Get it. At $3.75, I don't know what else on this planet at that price can be that fulfilling. If you know something, PM me. But until then..... Pour your own tea.
author: Yace H.

description: Very quick, easy, and affordable dim sum! Highly recommend to everyone coming to the Bay Area and Chinatown! Place may be crowded at times, but it's worth sitting down as It is a a very traditional dim sum restaurant!
author: Steven H.

description: Great value for what you get. Strong taste and flavors with bigger size of dim sum. The server was very curt and quick with no patience but she had an amazing ability to memorize our 8 item order while remembering other the orders from other tables too. Food was 4 stars the cleanliness was 2 stars. Still a great value
author: Ron-E H.

description: The most versatile dim sum catering in SF.  Scrumptious ideals at an inexpensive expenditures.  Always welcome with a fresh hot pot of aromatic tea selections.
author: Angela T.

description:
This place is interesting.  dark and dingy.  We didn't go with anyone who could speak Chinese, and our waitress didn't really speak English well, so it was a little hard to communicate.  I tried a few things, including the spare ribs... and I'm not a fan.  It was really fun though, an old Chinese man took my hand and showed me that sometimes I'm using my chopsticks wrong.  He didn't speak English either, but he kept smiling, and holding my hand and showing me how to hold it, and how to control different items.  I feel quite grateful to him, as just a few days ago, I went to a Chinese restaurant with a few friends, and my Chinese friend kept commenting on how I'm not holding the chopsticks like the other "white girls" in our group. lol. 

I guess, I might be too much of a dim sum snob.  or maybe, I just don't know good dim sum.  Either way, this place wasn't truly my favorite, just for the simple fact that I didn't leave thinking I definitely need to be back soon.
author: Moozhan T.

description:
Food is pretty okay. SO CHEAP OMG.
The service sucks as usual with dim sum places. Would recommend bringing someone that is able to speak because it is hard to get any food to your table. 
Restaurant is not the cleanest but not too bad.
author: Ori N.

description:
This is a cash only restaurant! It was great though.
We went on a Tuesday morning and it was quite busy.
The buns were huge and I could tell they were fresh made which naturally made them taste that much better.
There is no ambiance, just good food. It was also hella warm in there, but that might have been the pot of scalding hot tea.
The service is at most dim sum places but they were very accommodating of us non-Chinese speaking folk.
We had a couple shrimp buns, pork and shrimp shumai, bbq pork buns, sweet egg buns. All were the best I've ever had.
We'd definitely go back.
author: Lauren J.

description: Two hairs in my food. Some dishes were served cold. Very basic restaurant but seems to be packed with locals.
author: Linda W.

description:
Decent dim sum place in SF Chinatown. I used to come here pretty frequently with my family for early morning dim sum.

By far my favorite item at Dol Ho are their beef balls: they make the beef tender and juicy. Their pork spare ribs are also pretty decent, though a tad on the fatty side. Their other items were rather average.

One downside: the place is rather dirty.
author: Alvin W.

description:
Nothing beats great dim sum to start off the day in the city. The food is really cheap, but doesn't lack in authenticity. I love the pork rice, and I have to get it whenever I'm in the area. Just thinking about it makes my mouth water. The fried taro is pretty good too, but you really can't go wrong with anything here. 

I do have to warn you that service and cleanliness do not meet typical standards. You might have to share the table with strangers if you end up at a bigger table. To say the least, the atmosphere is the opposite of pretentious. As long as you come here with lowered expectations for customer service, you'll be rewarded with yummy food.
author: Catherine L.

description: I used to wonder why my mom always pick to eat here over those fancy restaurants like New Asia but now that I'm older I know why... Not only is it delicious it's also cheaper. It may look raggedy. It may look cheap. It may look hood. But for the price and taste it's a good bargain! They are known for their raw spare ribs. I see a lot of people buying it to go. I ate a few dishes here and my total was so cheap. I ate a few dishes somewhere with a fancy ambience and the total was so much. Now that I'm older I'm more than glad to come here with my mom because I appreciate the food more. I hope this place stay the way it is. I don't want them modernize and be all fancy. There is no need for that. I like everything old school. The way it is gives it more of an authentic feel. Definitely one of my favorite spots for cheap and authentic dim sum!
author: Jan E.

description:
My GF and I wanted good, authentic Chinese food. While walking through Chinatown we Yelp'ed this place and decided to try it. We were definitely not left disappointed.

It's a bit small and when we walked in there was a large crowd - we were lucky we got a table. Once we sat down we were promptly given hot tea, which was amazing.

We've never done Dim Sum before and because of the language barrier, it was a bit harder than we'd hoped but eventually we got the hang of it. We got pot stickers - some of the best I've ever had -, BBQ pork buns (some of the freshest I've ever tasted), and spare rib with black bean sauce. All of the food was amazing and the quantity was large enough that we actually got full. 

After all was said and done, our total was $11.75! Amazing food at great prices. I definitely want to return here next time I'm in SF.
author: Ana A.

description: This place has amazing dim sum but for a foreigner that doesn't speak any Mandarin it's very difficult to order. P.s. bring lots of cash
author: Jonathan Y.

description:
The previous comments are so true... you do get what you pay for here.  I'm sure all the regular customers here are just because it's cheap. The service is horrible and so are the food.  The food tasted so blend and the facility is so dirty.  The seating arrangement is horrible, they squeeze you in this little table with everyone else in the world.  

Yuck!
author: Jinnie H.

description: This place used to a hidden gem for dim sum if you didn't mind sharing a table with strangers, getting your own tea refills, or less than pristine bathrooms.  That being said, it was still my favorite place for dim sum in SF, for over 10 years.  My last visit was in August of 2017. The prices had really gone up and the selection was less than what I recalled from past years.  Skipped in this past week and instead picked up great tasting BBQ pork buns and Shu mai at Good Mong Kok.
author: Seong M.

description: Amazing dumplings. Feels very authentic. I'd recommend the shrimp with parsley and the pork dumplings. Sparerib was very tasty but it's quite oily for my taste. Would definitively recommend this place to my friends
author: Felipe D.

description: Great find, minimal service. 4 of us found a nice shared table about 12:46. Full of mostly regulars. No obvious menus. There is only one cart, with rotating types: steamed dumplings (shrimp, pork, others); fried; vegetables (stuffed eggplant, stuffed bell pepper); specials - today was braised pork ribs on a small bucket of rice.  Did not realize the steamed pork buns were up front and you had to ask. Best serving was potstickers, should have ordered more. Cash only. We had at least a dozen dishes, maybe more, for $32.
author: Dave Y.

description: I came here at dol ho a few years ago with my mom in the late afternoon after a long day grocery shopping , we bought some steamed beef balls siu mai including ha gow we both ate in the car before going home the food is not bad ,besides that I love seeing authentic minced steamed beef patty minced steamed pork over rice and oh my goodness steamed spare ribs over rice ,I have not yet eaten them but hopefully next time . I wish more mom and pops dim sum shops sell them in Chinatown coming out steaming piping hot !
author: Kimmie Z.

description:
TL;DR: Hit or miss. 

My first time at this place was fantastic. It was extremely crowded on a Saturday morning and the food was piping hot and delicious. Service was great and it was very cheap. 

My second time there, however, was a different experience. Despite visiting again on a Saturday afternoon, the restaurant was kind of empty. That should have been our red flag from the start. The lady at the front manning the cash register asked what tea we wanted, and my mother asked to give us a second to decide. When we flagged down that lady a few minutes later, she exclaimed "You weren't ready when I asked, and now I'm busy and you want your tea?" Damn, rude. 

You'd think that a well-known place that lacks in customer service would make up for it in quality of food, but that day's selection was quite meh compared to last time. Some of the dumplings were cold. The shrimp rice rolls were lukewarm and kind of pasty. 

This place doesn't function quite like a normal dim sum place. You need to constantly ask the server what you want because the place is so small, the cart won't physically get to your table. Where you get your food depends on what type of dish you want. The Wu Gok (taro balls) or Cha Siu Bao (BBQ pork buns) are actually pulled from the front counter where they are continually made for to-go orders. Fresh steamed dumplings come from the carts, if the cart is carrying what you're looking for at that moment. Random things are, I think, made fresh from the kitchen. 

This place was fairly cheap considering the quality and service. Before the new year, it was around $20 for 6 dishes. Apparently they raised their prices after the new year, so the second time around, it was $24 for around 7 dishes. 

Not sure if I'd come back for a third round. After the poor quality and service, I think I'm going to try another dim sum place in Chinatown.
author: Steven L.

description: Really great Dim Sum for really good prices. Chaotic, yes! What do you expect? It's a San Fran Dim Sum place with sub-2 buck sticky buns! But it's where the locals go so it's worth a visit. Will be back!
author: Justin E.

description:
Just ok. 

Mostly toothless old men patorns who talked way too loud. 

The ribs with black beans were a disappointment, picking the bone shards out of my mouth. 

The bbq pork bun filling was bland and sparse. 

Har gow, just ok. 

Steamed beef wrapped in wide rice noodle was the only dish worth mentioning. Tender, the filling was subtly seasoned with cilantro and water chestnut. 

Nah. The only benefit was being able to sit at a table rather than no where to eat, resorting to carrying around a lot of bags from the tiny bakeries.  But I'd much rather go to those tiny bakeries.
author: Wendy B.

description:
Um... is this place for real? Three of us ate our fill of delicious dimsum for just $17.75. I shit you not. We started with potstickers which are typically pretty boring for me, but these were pretty damn amazing. The shao mai was great. Xia Jiao was great. Meatball thingy was good. Every single thing we ordered was excellent. Love!

This is a real hole-in-the-wall. Knowing Mandarin came in handy. There were some items on the menu that weren't available, which was too bad. I had some trouble understanding the process involved... Took me a while to figure out whether they were regularly bringing carts around or if you had to order off the menu. I still don't think I have it completely figured out, but I believe it's a mixture of both.
author: Jenn C.

description:
Dol Ho is a small dim sum restaurant where locals come to eat. My friends and I (6 in total) came here on a rainy Saturday morning just before 11am. We were seated at the large round table in the back and were soon joined by three others. Sharing a table with strangers is the norm here so don't be alarmed. The restaurant had a few tables available when we arrived but by the time we were leaving, new customers were at our tables ready to swoop in for the seats. I recommend coming here early (before 11) to grab a table.

There is one cart in the entire restaurant. The woman parks the cart in the middle of the restaurant and will go to each table asking for their orders. Especially if the restaurant is busy, I recommend ordering everything at once (4-6 dishes) because it will take a long time before you'll be able to get your food. My friends and I ordered 12 dishes which totaled at $60 with tip. While we ordered many dishes, I greatly enjoyed the pork short ribs over rice. The dishes are cheap so go wild and try all the different dim sum dishes.
author: Katie C.

description:
The best dimsum I've had my whole life! Exceeded my expectations. Dimsums and dumplings are fresh and simply mouth watering!

It gets busy here though and since you only order noodles while the rest of the items you have to wait for from the cart form the inside, the wait will kill you! :) that wait is worth it though and every 5mins or so, they take out the cart and you get to grab your food! So yummy!

Just be careful, they only accept cash! No cards!
author: Katrina B.

description: Came here for dim sum with the boo. It's a no frills kind of spot complete with: lots of old people eating dim sum, little English, confusion about where to sit (pro tip #1: find any open seat and sit there--quickly!), and people not really paying attention to you (pro tip #2: stand up and walk to the cart, or wave people over or you're never gonna get any food). The food itself was good, not the best dim sum I've had, but gets the job done and at a good price. They don't always have everything on the menu, so good luck waving down the cart ladies!
author: Joanna C.

description: Came here for lunch with family craving dim sum. As a tourist looking in, I had a feeling this place would be good seeing how it was full of locals even though it was a definite hole in the wall. Dim sum was excellent, ordered the Hargow, Shu mai, pork ribs and pork dumplings to name a few. Don't expect the ambiance to be the greatest but if quality dim sum is what you're looking for, this is it. On an additional note, you have to pass through all the cooks and the kitchen to get to the shared washroom in the back which was an interesting experience to say the least.
author: Cliff V.

description:
TL:DR - Dirty tables. Not a lot of food (especially if you sit far from the kitchen) Loud. Cheap. 

Small place close to Stockton street easy access. The restaurant is a small area with about twelve tables each table holds four people. front there are some dim sum that you can take out but if you eat those food in the restaurant ITs A Different Price. It's also very loud.
This place is dirty, flies everywhere, the tables they wipe with the same dirty oily towel and my table is still dirty. They push out a cart at what feels like forever and by the time the cart goes around all he food will be gone so closer to the kitchen the better chance you'll get food if you sit near the door you might just starve to death. And they don't let you go get the food. But why is there so many people here always full, because it's CHEAP. Foods alright though I didn't eat much cause I sat near the door... all the good stuff if any were gone.
author: Herman X.

description: Decent food but terrible service as expected.  Good dumplings and spare ribs and chicken feet.  Shu mai and BBQ pork buns are not good.  Spare rib rice is okay.
author: Alison D.

description: Authentic Dim Sum!!! Hit this place .. Don't expect something fancy restaurant here !!!but food wise .. You won't regret it .. It's like bringing Hong Kong to the Bay Area..for $ you'll be a happy camper after 3 small plate ..
author: Donovan L.

description:
So this place will put you out of your comfort zone, it is noisy, crowded and no frills. At the same time there is A palpable energy to the place.
