When you come in you have to try to find a seat as quickly as you can as there is no seating service. Once you find a seat waitress shortly comes up and gives you chopsticks and plates and starts bringing food. There are no menus. You wait and the waitress brings you different dishes and you decide if you want them or not. We tried spare ribs and shrimp dumplings before seasoned perfectly and came piping hot. Don't be afraid to be adventurous year as you may not know exactly what you're ordering but don't be afraid.

A quick tip this is cash only so make sure you have some when you arrive, also you may end up waiting in line because there is a line out the door.
author: David A.

description:
The food is okay but some of them are cold.

They have an okay selection of dim sum. I like the pork dumpling because they put mushroom in it. The shrimp dumpling is okay.

All fried items are not freshly fried so they can be cold. I also don't like their taro cake because I think it's too doughy and they should put more taro in it.

The service is fast and friendly. The place is relatively clean and they have bathroom for customers.
author: Tiratat P.

description:
So, you're here. Come in and find spots. Smaller groups (3-4) will almost always win out over large ones and pairs are the ace in the hole. If you need to just find random spots at a table and sit and wait til people finish eating or wait by a table for the same reason. No one's gonna shoo you away for being annoying, this is all communal so release your fears of sitting next to someone you don't know. The staff will figure out they're gone, clear it out and give you utensils and a pot of tea. Carts will come around, yes it helps immensely if you speak Cantonese but you can honestly get by pretty easily if you just wave down the cart as it comes by and point at random things for her to open and show you. Eat well, the food is GREAT. Once you're done, take your bill to the front cashier to be rung up and head on out. Prices are decent but obviously if you order a lot, your bill will be high, but no more than $30-$40 on the very high end (for 2 at least). Even if you do somehow, I think you'll reconcile that with how happy your stomach is.

Recommend getting the spare ribs + rice, shrimp balls, rice noodles. (Siu mai, har gow implied as everyone orders them)

And so I dislike most uses of the word authentic. I feel that authenticity is incredibly relative to each person's experience and that while it can help when properly framed, a lot of people put too much emphasis on it. Regardless, I grew up frequenting the old school classic dim sum restaurants of Old LA Chinatown and 626 (San Gabriel). Take that as you will, I've had a lot of dim sum in my life and to my point, while I can say that this has been the most difficult place to ever order in, that doesn't take away from it at all and it's somewhere I plan on going back to 150%.

Also as a final note, I'm always a bit confused when I see long lists of dissent against lackluster service and atmosphere at Chinese restaurants. The onus is always on the food and especially so here as it's meant to be a fast joint for locals. Don't hate it for that, respect the fact that it's a place that remains true to the community through the years and celebrate that you are able to be a part of that history.
author: Charles M.

description: Ate here in early November 2017. Interesting experience, fun, a little challenging to figure out what on the menu we wanted to eat. Hole in the wall, authentic dim sum experience, popular with local older Chinese folks.
author: Jake G.

description:
Best, Cheapest Food in ALL OF SAN FRAN, cuz San Fran will suck out all your money out of your wallet!

But seriously as an asian growing up in ny, i've had my fair share of dim sum. Heck I don't even know why ppl think San Fran Chinatown is all that great, Walking up and down hills is silly and annoying, and i was only here for a few days.

However this place is awesome, really grungy place, not grimy, just feels "old" cuz all the patrons are old grandmas and grandpas. I came in here expecting to be seated and a grandpa went right past me and sat down, guess this place is it!

Grandpas and Grandmas know good food, heck, they've been eating it longer than you, they also know good cheap food!

Get the usual Dim Sum fair, make sure to the pork and rice. Obviously come early before 12.
author: James W.

description:
Very small dim sum place in the heart of Chinatown SF. The sparerib with rice and cilantro fun with shrimp was okay. But I really liked their ha gow (shrimp dumpling). 

Service was fast. I was a bit skeptical about how clean everything is...definitely one of those hole-in-the-wall places!
author: Eva L.

description:
I will preface this review with the fact that 1) I am horribly picky when it comes to dim sum and 2) My friend and I showed up at 2:15, 45 minutes before they closed shop and 3) My only comparison is NYC because I was visiting the area for the first time. Also, I'm fluent in Chinese and know my Chinese food.

With that being said, this place is gross.  It would normally only get 1 star from me but because of the reasons mentioned above, I'll give it a benefit of the doubt. It's cheap enough, regular dishes are $2.50 and large/special dishes are $3.50. 

Out of 7 dishes, 6 were reheated and I suspect more than one. The protein had been cooked to the point where the texture and wrapping around it had changed. This means one thing to me - it was left overs for the day. Now out of the 6 reheated dishes, only about half as actually warm.

My only complaint is this - either stop serving early or do it well regardless. If I was the owner, I would be  ashamed to serve this food of this quality. My friend and I were hungry and desperate so we ate most if it. However, I will not be returning in the future with so many other options down the street.

The restaurant itself was your typical dingy Chinese place. Somewhat sticky and uneven tables. I guess you get what you pay for.
author: Joey R.

description:
I was on the fence whether to give 4 or 5 stars, but overall went for the perfect score because there really isn't much that disappoints about this place, as long as you go in with low expectations on ambience/decor/service. I know that sounds like a contradicting statement but you'll see once you go. And yes -- if you're ok with a totally no-frills type establishment to get great food at an exceptional price -- you should absolutely GO.

You walk in and it seems like you've taken a wrong turn and wandered into some community center cafeteria or something. There are a few ladies meandering through the tables looking expressionless (or bored out of their minds) wearing aprons, these are your stewards for the Dol Ho experience. Grab a seat, pour out your dipping sauces, and ask for a menu. 

The food is not particularly fast, but it all came within a reasonable time. Plenty of interesting people watching in the meantime. This place is frequented mainly by Chinatown locals and regulars, most of whom are old and ain't got time for any nonsense. You will hear Chinese spoken throughout the room. Once you order, you will get a pot of hot tea which will be your best friend as you slurp down delicious dim sum dumplings and buns.

Most menu items are well prepared, delicious and very simply flavored -- nothing over complicated, experimental, frou frou, or designer farm-to-table here. A few faves: the deep fried shrimp balls, steamed pork buns (very abundant with tasty, flavorful filling), shrimp and chive dumplings, chicken nests (a chunk of chicken wrapped in a nest of clear cellophane noodles). We're talking solid, old school, traditional dim sum. And if frugality is an Olympic sport for you, you will be scoring gold medals here. It just doesn't get any cheaper than this for really solid dim sum. Period.

Make sure to bring cash, use a bathroom before you head over, and prepare to stuff your bellies.

*PARENT ADVICE* Doesn't seem like they had any highchairs for little ones.
author: M. M.

description:
Old school with one cart that they reload so if you want dibs, as with all dim sum joints try to sit closer to the kitchen (on the left side of the restaurant looking inside from the street).

Lots of standard fare and if you have something you want (like a noodle roll) you can just ask the waitress for it. Also don't be offended if you're in a party of 2 and they move you to a shared table when a large group comes in. This is the way of the world and we all get to eat more when we're flexible about stuff.

The most unique dish I saw was this pork spareribs over rice bowl where I think the whole thing is steamed together, letting that sweet pork juice get in to the rice. It's not the best for splitting but tastes great.
author: Misha T.

description:
Wow, this restaurant is definitely an experience! We walked in thinking we were gonna get our order taken and be served like in a normal restaurant, right? Wrong! 

A lady appears, coming around with hot trays on a cart and offering different dishes you can accept to have or not. We were lucky as the two first dishes we would have ordered anyway: pork and shrimp dumplings. Great portion sizes for two to share (about 2 pretty big pieces each), very fresh and tasty and unbeatable prices (2,50$-3,50$ per plate to share!). 

After a few minutes wondering how we were gonna order specific dishes we had seen on the menu, we asked for BBQ Pork Bun that happened to be on the tray and got it immediately. Best bun ever!! (see picture). We then decided to try the ribs over rice which were okay (lots of bones and very tiny pieces). We finished with huge fried shrimp dumplings. Very particular but I liked it! 

We were very full coming out of there and the prices were so cheap: 17$ for all of that and free tea served right when we got there. I would recommend this place for having good dim sum and an original lunch where you won't leave hungry!
author: Leslie S.

description: We stumbled upon this place while on a short trip to San Francisco. This is a pretty simple and humble restaurant in the middle of Chinatown, and it is cash only. From the moment you walk in you can tell that it's one of those places that's frequent by the same people everyday. The service was mediocre at best but that's pretty normal places for Asian restaurants. The food was pretty good, i didn't think it was the best meal I've ever had but everything was fresh, flavorful and authentic. It was also pretty cheap, 3 of us basically stuffed ourselves for $30.
author: Mery R.

description: [UPDATE] I heard Dol Ho is open again, woo hooO!!
author: Audrey L.

description: Definitely wouldn't recommend you to come here if you're into nice ambience and doesn't speak any Chinese. It's an authentic Asian dim sum place, the food is delicious and really cheap! They only have one cart going around, so it's easier to order off the menu if you know what you want. It's also cash only!
author: Michelle C.

description: This dim sum place is just awesome.  People said their spare ribs over steamed rice is best, but i live the chicken over steamed rice.  Price very reasonable.
author: Denis Y.

description:
Best dim sum served ever with free fragrant hot tea!  We ordered:
- standard shrimp (har gow) and pork (shumai) dumplings but there was nothing standard about it!  Super flavorful with such thin and slightly chewy wrapping paper that you can see right through the filling! 
- spareribs over rice was pure heaven in a small tin bowl. The ribs were cooked perfectly and juices laced through to the rice packed in the bottom of the bowl. So good that I was secretly battling the urge to order an extra portion to take to-go!
- stuffed eggplant.  Looks very unassuming but just packed with flavor and perfect ratio between filling and eggplant. 
- chicken feet..omg, juicy fat chicken feet...nom nom nom
- stuffed bean noodle dish that I've never had before.  Bean thread noodles filled with ground chicken, ground pork, mushroom and tofu. Deliciousness!

No soy sauce needed just top it off with housemate chili paste in oil - not usual standard chili paste but chili paste on steroids full of flavor a such as black bean sauce and garlic. 

This is a HOLE-IN-THE-WALL place smack in the middle of SF Chinatown. Don't expect a lot a fancy ambiance with waitstaff that can speak English. We sat community seating with a table of 4 older Chinese people that cannot speak English well. Signs of good restaurant people - old native diners!

Restaurant was so busy that they literally sat us at the table and cleared out dirty dishes as we are being seated...barely wiping the table clean. But the dumpling is so amazing that it more than makes up for the ambiance.  

Super tasty food but set your expectation correctly in the decor and lack of English speakers. Lucky it's a dim sum restaurant so you can pretty much point at what you want when the cart is pushed around :)
author: Diem P.

description:
Food: 5 stars. The dim sums very tasty here, especially for the price. 
Service (waitress): 5 stars. There was one poor waitress was running around, working hard, waiting on the whole restaurant. 
Service (owners): 0 stars. The owners were manning the cashier and bussing. I felt bad for the waitress, and left a hefty tip, which one of the owners promptly scooped up and put into his own pocket!  Doh! Lesson learned, don't tip in Chinatown, the cash doesn't make it to the staff!
author: Andy C.

description: Came here because a friend wanted their spareribs and rice. So as I waited I see the lady up front picking up some dim sum for the older lady while the kitchen is bringing out the spareribs. The taro cake when sliding back ended up falling and hitting the glass. As the waitress pulled the tray back the cake dragged across the glass some more. And that's all she did, just to resell at a later time.
author: M C.

description:
If you want authentic dim sum...this is the place. It's like a hole in the wall full of people all the time. We went there for lunch on a Friday at 11.30. You have to be really outgoing to go to this place vacate if you are not Chinese good luck not looking out of place. We were definitely the back sheep in this place but we were sat immediately and treated with an awkward but welcoming smile :) 

They brought out different types of shrimp dim sum. One was just shrimp wrapped in rice paper and the other one was with scallions. We also had the bbq pork buns and the sticky rice. This was probably the freshest and most authentic tasting dim sum my fiancé and I ever had.

You really get a feel for Chinatown in San Fran and the authentic flavored of the east. They even make their own spicy chili sauce. Overall delicious and a must if you are feeling adventurous and inspired!
author: Henry S.

description:
I can't believe it took me this long to find out about this place.  Don't expect a gorgeous extravagantly decorated dim sum restaurant.  This is the ultimate definition of a functional eatery that only needs to serve the best food-the surroundings are superfluous.  

We were craving dim sum in the area of chinatown but didn't want the touristy spot as most people would lean towards.  I was skeptical of this place due to the subpar reviews, but the chinese in me said 'maybe the best ones aren't reviewed.' Sure enough dol ho made that cut.  

We go in and notice most of the elder diners there looked like they eat here on a daily basis making themselves quite at home.  Not many young folks but us.  I'm all for changing the motto.  First thing--we scour and spy on neighboring tables to see what's thee dish to get- turns out it tin can with spareribs over rice.  Well then we have to get that.  Such a simple dish and it was satiating.  it has the perfect balance of flavor with tender ribs.  Since we sat right by the kitchen opening I got to ooooo and aaahhh at the dishes being made.  The one dish constantly churning out were the ribs over rice.   Most of the dim sum dishes are requested since there is one cart lady catering to all the tables.  You better know the dishes you want.  Every dish was perfectly seasoned- turnip cake, shrimp dumpling, rice roll, steamed pork bun and rice crepe.  I can't remember a bad dish and believe me there usually is one at most spots.  

I'm so happy they open at 8 in the morning.  I will definitely be coming back for more of that rib over rice.  Plenty of people came in to only buy that.
author: Dee L.

description: This place is literally a hole in the wall. If i didn't know about this place, I would never walk in and eat here since it looks so old and dirty. However, my mom has been coming here for spare ribs and the chicken leaf wrap to go. This place has the best spareribs. I have tried so many spareribs from other dimsum places but nothing is even comparable this one. Everything is cheap and i definitely recommend everyone to come here. I have yet dined in, but one day i will
author: Allie Y.

description:
I was seeking out a dim sum experience like one I had a few years ago in Seattle - where the workers bring out a cart stacked high with bamboo boxes containing fresh dim sum. I found it here. You are seated at a shared table and served tea. Most often dim sum places do jasmine tea and that's what I poured out from my individual tea kettle. There is no doubt this is a traditional sort of place and it didn't take me very long to realize that with all the locals dining and chatting in Chinese around me.

The woman first came around with Ha Gow and Pork Dumplings. The Ha Gow (shrimp) was perfectly made and didn't need any soy sauce or seasoning. The pork dumplings were equally as perfect and the meaty, oily juices leaked out when I ate them. Both dim sum were served piping hot.

After I savored my dumplings, I told the woman I was waiting for pork spare ribs with rice. I waited for 5 or so minutes when a huge cart of the stuff was brought out. The sauce was amazing and the spare ribs I chewed off the bone. Everything was again piping hot, including the metal bowl the spare ribs were served in (so be careful)!

For this filling meal, I paid $10.60. Cash only!
author: Beth P.

description:
Dol Ho has been around for over 24 years & they serve authentic, good dim sum at very reasonable prices.  

BEST CHILI OIL IN THE WORLD: 
Dol Ho makes the best Chinese chili oil/sauce in the world that I've ever had. (There is a Chinese restaurant in Melbourne, Australia that makes the 2nd best.)  Dol Ho's homemade chili oil is so tasty, but it's hard to describe. It's the perfect balance of spicy & savoury (from pickled radish or something?) & it's a wonderful accompaniment to fried rice. Dol Ho's chili oil alone is worth the trip. And I do mean this literally -- I was in SF on a stopover & went to Dol Ho especially to buy some chili sauce to bring home.  I may have booked my flights/stopover with this chili oil in mind.

DIM SUM IS ALSO GOOD:

1. Radish cake: Very prominent radish flavour, which is as it should be. Most places make their radish cake with too much flour filler but here at Dol Ho, it actually tastes like radish. The texture was mushy (not good), but on the whole, this was still good & comforting.

2. Braised chicken feet (fung zao) was braised to tenderness and flavourful.

3. Chicken drumsticks cooked in tin foil is pretty tasty, with a nice sauce.

4. Shrimp dumplings (har gao) was solid. Not the best, but not bad.

5. Stuffed eggplant was not very good. It was okay but just not as flavourful as other dishes they make.

The dim sum cost around $15.  It was enough to feed 2 at lunch.  I spent another $20 on chili oil to fly back home.
author: Shereen C.

description: This place is terrible. We came at 2pm on a Friday. The server not only didn't wait for me to finish my order before leaving but also served us cold food. When we complained she disconnectedly said that it was all they had left. The food was incredibly mediocre and we were very disappointed especially given how many raving reviews there were.
author: Allen Y.

description:
The food and prices here are unbeatable. Their spare rib rice is what they're known for and its only $3.75! Did I mention how delicious it is? It was so good I had to come again the next day. On the first day, we dined in and everything was fine. We received decent service, especially for Chinatown. As for the second day I wanted to order to go. I walk in there and the worker is sitting behind the counter staring off into space. I asked her for two spare rib rices to go and she quickly runs to the kitchen to get it and comes back in about 2 mins. (They always have their rices ready cause it's basically all anyone orders). I then asked her for extra soy sauce cause I didn't get to ask before she ran off. This was where the lady looked pissed and said "There's already soy sauce in here, why didn't you ask me earlier?" Like are you serious? You're sitting there staring off into space and your mad that you have to walk an extra 5 ft to the kitchen to get me more soy sauce? You should be grateful a paying customer is giving you something to do. But this is Chinatown, and I know better to rate based on service. 

5/5 for food and price 
3/5 for cleanliness 
2/5 for service
author: Lushi Z.

description: Locals dominate the patronage here. It is a little hole in the wall with very good dim sum. One has to be a little aggressive to get your food and possibly a seat, but it is worth it. Good food, great prices. We shared a table with a couple of older women. They even shared some of their choices to encourage us to try authentic dim sum. If in San Francisco again I would return.
author: Lisa H.

description: We had the fried shrimp rice ball, pork dumplings, and chicken in foil. It was amazing - the best dim sum I've ever had. Even the tea was phenomenal! A truly authentic experience everyone should have!
author: Jacquie H.

description:
There are many dim sum places in Chinatown, but none are like this one. 

I went with my family for lunch. It was crowded with people. We ordered some dim sum and an item from the main course. Although the dim sum was easy to get, it was hard to get the main course. Had to ask for it twice. Overall, nice place to eat needs a bit of expansion.
author: Alex L.

description: One of those hole in the wall restaurants in Chinatown. Dol Ho has been around for decades and is known for their Spare Ribs. I usually get their Spare Ribs Rice and the Vegetarian Rice Rolls. The Spare Ribs Rice is steamed and topped with Soy Sauce, this is a must get for everyone and is one of the most popular dishes. The Vegetarian Rice Rolls has cilantro with a soft texture. There is no service at this restaurant, meaning customers seat themselves at a table and pay at the counter after their meal. This restaurant is always busy year round and is packed with regulars. There is a laminated English menu for those who do not speak Chinese, but I would bringing a friend who can speak Chinese. The owner of the restaurant is the chef that you see walking around serving the customers. He used to only work in the back, but now runs the entire restaurant himself after his wife went into retirement a few years back. Again, most of the customers are regulars at this restaurant, where the staff would remember their orders and what kind of tea they would drink. All the tables are usually occupied during their peak hours and sharing a table is a must. Not the cleanest restaurant, but they try their best since it run down from being around for decades. They did remodel the restaurant in the recent years and cleaned the dirty fans along the wall. Hopefully they stay around for the years to come. They are one of the last restaurants in Chinatown that actually still uses carts to serve dim sum. This rating is for the food, I can care more or less about the cleanliness of this restaurant. I have been coming here since I was toddler with my grandpa and have never experienced a problem with their food. He is a regular at Dol Ho and has been coming here every morning 365 days a year. Please do not come here with debit or credit cards, they only take cash.
author: Peter C.

description: Not your typical Cantonese dim sum. Variety of food is limited. Not the best but also not the worst. There are way better dim sums out there!
author: Wendy C.

description: Dol Ho is back open again!  Looking nice and fresh. So happy my favorite dim sum spot is back again
author: Dean L.

description:
My fellow coffee enthusiast friend from HK and I have this unspoken tradition whenever I'm back in town where we spend a morning doing yamcha and then visiting some up-and-coming coffee joint in the City.

Whereas our last few iterations have been at a certain well-established dim sum restaurant in Serramonte, my buddy insisted we give this one a try, mainly because his "non-Asian friends don't want to eat some place this dirty."

To clarify, Dol Ho is not dirty in the sense that one should worry about the hygienic integrity of its food, but in the sense that it's quick and dirty, kind of like the 7 AM Cha Chaan Tengs in Yau Ma Tei -- that being said, any review that complains about the "service" or the lack thereof, should promptly be ignored and its writer possibly scrutinized and beat over the head with a burlap sack filled with soap.

Excessively violent images aside, Dol Ho is, as aforementioned, like one of the many dim sum quick stops that line the side of Nathan Road and Kowloon; the moment you set foot in the store, you're ushered in to sit at their communal tables (I hope you don't have an irrational fear of sitting next to strangers!) after which they bring the food out to you as soon as they're prepared right out of the kitchen, and you order simply by either saying "I want that" or I guess pointing at it.

The quality of food you get here highly outweighs the price point -- the spare ribs w/rice seems to be the popular pick here for a quick bite; their cheung fun, har gow, siu mai, and various char siew offerings are all excellent and well worth the parking adventure downtown you will most likely have to take to eat here.

All in all, a great option for dim sum downtown.
author: Scott S.

description:
Upon a fellow Yelp Elite's recommendation, we tried this place out. 

It was filled with locals which is always a great sign. It's very unassuming and no frills. There is a counter at the front which you can order to-go items from, which seemed to be pretty popular. The place was packed with elders reading the newspaper, some solo and other catching up with old friends. It has a homey feel.

You can pretty much seat yourself, but since the place was packed and we hadn't been there before, the server cleared out a spot for us. The tables are all kinda joined together, so you'll probably be sitting next to others. This doesn't seem to be a place to linger. The tables turn over quickly. Plenty of people just come in for one dish, read the paper, drink some tea, and leave. However, service was friendly and we did not feel rushed.

They were quick to give us tea, and our chopsticks and plates, so we were ready to go. There was only one woman with a cart, but she was regularly coming out with fresh new items. You can easily see into the open kitchen, so you can see them preparing all the new dishes to bring out. 

Even though the two us ordered at least two more dishes after we were already stuffed (and took home our leftovers: 2 large fried shrimp dumplings, 2 turnips cakes, and 2 pieces of beef crepe), we left so stuffed and it all cost less than $20 total. This place is cheap! 

Someone helpfully posted pictures of the menu on here, which was nowhere to be seen in the restaurant, so although, they don't serve a huge variety of dishes, I still thought this place was solid. It's super cheap, service is quick, and the dishes were good. There were no super-amazing dishes that were memorable, but everything was solid. 

As everyone mentions, the Rib Rice was a good dish that I'm glad we ordered. Watch out for the bones though. 

I'd definitely come back here again.
author: Rebecca G.

description:
This place was ridiculous...ly amazing. I took some friends here for dim sum, and we spent a total of $5 each for possibly the best dim sum I've ever had. The pork ribs are so flavorful. Everything was delicious. There is only one woman pushing around a cart, so the service is a little slow, and the selection isn't HUGE but the quality and price of the food makes up for it. I will be back the next time I'm in the SF area. 
Also note: I tried a different dim sum place the day before (apparently where Obama and Stephen Hawking are) which was more expensive and decorated but it has NOTHING on this place.
author: Hao Z.

description: I don't remember the last time I was here, but for some reason I have vague memories of spareribs over rice being served in metal bowls. Looked tasty. Unfortunately they've been closed by the Health Department.
author: Henry P.

description: I have has dim sum at quite a few places, from NYC to LA to Houston and San Fran Chinatowns.  The best dim sum at local mom & pop, non tourist trap restaurant.  The Steamed Stuffed Bean Roll, Spareribs over Rice, the Chicken Feet, shrimp dumplings, pork dumplings, chicken stuffed eggplant are heavenly tasting!  The Spare Ribs over Rice tops it all!!! And it's cheap!!! And they have their own spicy chili oil where you don't even need soy sauce!
author: Janet T.

description: Good food.  Speaking no Chinese, the woman working helped me navigate the menu.  It wasn't the cleanest (I saw an elderly woman spit on the floor and keep on eating), but I wouldn't say it was out of place if that makes sense.  Pork buns were good, so were chives.  Many people on Yelp raved about the ribs but I think I ordered the wrong thing, as it was mostly bone and not very good.  Overall, if I was headed back to San Fran and wanted dim sum I'd stop by again.
author: Anne M.

description:
This was my favorite place in ctown. Came down today for my bday lunch. This place closed due to sanitary issues. I had no problems with it. This place was old school. Not going to find anything like this anymore. Don't think they will be coming back!! 

Dedicate this song to you guys up in Dol Ho!

https://youtu.be/ywmNcVh7lsE
author: RICKY C.

description: It was not crowded, the food was mediocre. The dumplings here are good, the spare ribs over rice was pretty tasty but none of the food made me feel over the moon. There's definitely better places than this place in my opinion.
author: Julie C.

description: i think my experience would have been INFINITELY better if i spoke cantonese or knew exactly what was available to order at dol ho.  with that said though, everything i has was pretty good - i was just confused as to what was available! this joint is PACKED with locals and elderly canto folks (with a few hipsters here n there), so you know the stuff is legit.  will be back next time with canto speaking people!
author: Christina L.

description:
Best bang for your buck.

Dim sum quality is pretty good here. Don't be surprised when you get there and you end up sharing a table with strangers. Went with my friend and we ended up sharing a table with 5 other people.

The food comes out from the kitchen on a push cart fresh and they go from table to table. The cart is small but has a lot of variety. Let them know what you want. Much easier if you speak the language, but if you don't, just point at what you like. 

Downside I would say is not very clean and you lack privacy. Place is small and stuffy. Food is good and well worth the price though.
author: David H.

description:
Cheap, cheap dim sum. So cheap you get up and get your own tea if you're not willing to wait for a server, and no one will be offended.

Some sort of rice or rice noodle dish is very popular here, but we didn't know what it was called and never got around to finding out. The pai gut fan (pork sparerib over rice) is also hugely popular and is quite good considering how cheap it is.

Deep fried shrimp ball, har gow, shu mai are all just okay-- cheap and adequate is the order of the day here. Taro balls were HUGE and a little too cool inside, but the sesame balls were superb.

Inside, cheap tables, a horde of old Chinese men and women, shared tables, fans on the walls, reminded me very strongly of Hong Kong. Heck, about as strong a resemblance as I've seen to HK short of going there... for a legit HK experience, this is about as authentic as it gets in the states.
author: Brian W.

description: My favorite place to get their spareribs with rice dish! Out of the many chinese restaurants that I have been to, this is by far the best for their spareribs! They offer it cooked and raw and marinated as well. If i want to eat it some other day, for a quick meal that I can place in the rice cooker to steam, I buy it raw from them. If I'm eating it on the spot, i usually get it cooked and it'll come with rice too! Definitely affordable and tastes amazing!
author: Bailey L.

description: Good food for good price. Especially liked the ribs, crepes, and pork buns. Only thing that was kind of disappointing was the pastry-ish foods (sesame balls, fried taro, etc) were cold because they're kept in the front. Service might be a little hard for non Chinese-speaking people
author: Betty H.

description:
Delicious dim sum.

Not very English-friendly.

Come with a Cantonese-speaking friend for best experience.

Things to try:
Spare ribs over rice
Bean curd roll
Turnip cakes
author: Ananya M.

description: What is everyone raving about? The place is dirty and the food average. Also they run out of everything and the service sucks.
author: Gryffin Z.

description:
Weird and lovely.

One cart at a time, and it's a sh!tshow. Don't bother ordering anything else because its futile, unless you want a pork bun from the window, but the pork bun isn't anything to write home about. 

We ordered about 7 dishes and the bill came out to $18.

Just grab what you can and enjoy.
author: Rod A.

description:
This was a great experience and about as authentic as you can get. 

We stumbled in on a cold Saturday. Space is tight and the restaurant was packed. We ended up sharing a table w/ another party which worked out well because he told us what to order. The food was delicious. The clientele is overwhelmingly Chinese and most of the people seemed to know one another. 

All the staff does not necessarily speak English but they are happy to accommodate you. Just hang back for a bit and watch the locals...you sometimes need to approach the dim sum cart because of space restrictions...you will be able to get food and be glad you did. 

We stuffed ourselves (2 people) for slightly more than $20.
author: Mary Beth L.

description: A true hole in the wall.  The place is well used, a little tattered around the edges and legit.  The black bean spare ribs are worth waiting for.  I found the pot stickers a little thick on the wrapper/dough, but, the filling was super flavorful.  It was fun to see the hoards rush up from their table when a new cart of goodies came out of the kitchen.  Very interactive dim sum.  I suggest go early because the place was packed solid.  Bonus points because the little old lady near me was amused and (I hope) impressed at my chopstick skills.  They do a large, somewhat disorganized to-go business.  The place is busy, disorganized and the food was very good.  Would totally come back, we need more people with us because we ate far too much.
author: Donna H.

description: Our cab driver recommended this small restaurant for the best dim sum in San Francisco and he was absolutely right.  It's small,  loud, crowded with "ok" service but the food was amazing.   Highly recommend this place to anyone looking for authentic dim sum.
author: Shauna G.

description:
CASH ONLY!!!!!!!

You know a Chinese place is a great place when it's filled with nothing but Chinese people.  My bf was the only white boy in there the whole time.  The place is dive-y with not much of a decor, faded awning outside and super busy inside.  Not the cleanest walls and windows.  

I speak Mandarin and I even had a little trouble ordering.  The lady that pushed the cart around didn't speak Mandarin nor English... and I made the assumption that she didn't speak Spanish either, I pulled out my best point-and-nod skills.

Not really a fan of their har-gao (shrimp dumpling), the dough was really thick and I've had better in Denver.  The foil wrapped Chicken was awesome!  Saw a lady walked in for a take-out order and she got 3 orders (3 pieces per order) of those foil chickens.  I think it's the top segment of the chicken leg, wrapped and cooked in foil.  It's got awesome flavor throughout the whole chicken and super tasty!  I'm so glad I got it even though she couldn't tell me what was inside.  

Had pork spareribs, their most famous dish.  Most of the older Chinese crowd gets it over rice, we just got it standalone and it was delicious!  A little fattier than what I'm used to, it has great flavor with the black beans.  Also ordered the beef meatballs and they were delicious as well with chopped up water chestnuts inside.  Fried stuffed tofu triangles were delicious as well, just wish they were hot when we got them.  

Love their homemade chili sauce, not very spicy but it's different than anywhere else I've ever been to.  They used dried daikon (white radish), black bean and chili flake to make it.. not sure if there's a little garlic in it too.  Yummy!

For all 5 dishes with oolong tea came out to $16 after tax.  I don't think the waitress there gets tipped because when I handed her $2 she quickly grabbed it, smile and nod at me, and shoved the money in her apron as if that was the first tip she's got all day or that she didn't want others to see.  I know older Chinese people don't usually tip and that's the majority of the customers there.  

I would recommend if you tip, give it to the person that took care of you directly and not just leave it up at the front counter when you pay.  The lady behind the counter is not the nicest person and people have a tendency to cut in front of you.  If you give the tip to the lady upfront she will take it and not sure if she even distributes it to other workers.  Waiting in line is not really the best qualities of Chinese people and it shows at this restaurant.  

Overall, knowing what I was getting myself into, this place is awesome.  Been here 4 years ago when visited San Francisco and now coming back again for more.  And if you don't want people sharing tables with you, this might not be the place to try.  However, this is the cheapest and the best dim sum in the area with the best prices!
author: Sara C.

description:
I often stop by here in the mornings before work for some quick breakfast -- usually a pork bun or vegetable bun, so I never got to try their famous pork over rice. 

But their har gow and other vegetable/chive dumplings are amazing! The rice layer on the outside is thin and delicious and the insides are full of stuffing! 

Would definitely recommend if you're looking for great hole in the wall dim sum!
author: Jeanette S.

description: Authentic and well priced. A real hidden gem, and the dim sum is excellent. Will definitely be back for more
author: Gannon J.

description: I recommend their sticky rice, pork, and buns. I should try their pottage and soup next time.
author: Christy C.

description:
Dol Ho is as legit as it comes. Located in the heart of Chinatown, DH follows the old-style dim sum tea houses, minus the birds in cages and spit buckets, but keep the 70+ year olds and brusque service.

Seeing that it was a large group of 20s and 30s somethings, our hostess* asked the 2 older gentlemen (who reminded me of my grandpas - RIP) in the only large table to move to a smaller table. We felt bad and absolutely didn't mind sharing the table, but the gentle and kind grandpas assured us in Toisan that they were more than happy to move. Naturally, we helped them with their plates. 

The service is an acquired taste. If you're not used to the abrasiveness that older Chinese restaurants offers, you'll definitely be turned off. But hey, my friends and I grew up in the mean streets of Flushing and Chinatown in NYC. If we can't appreciate this, we might as well swear off Chinese food forever. 

Food is great! It's only 1 cart with 1 lady pushing the cart, so they try to fit as much as they can on it. And you never know what they come out with, but feel free to put in orders! Reading Yelp, we did see that the marinated meats over rice were the must-gets. So we tried the spare ribs over rice, chicken over rice, and pork patty with preserved fish over rice. All three gets the thumbs up. So good that we each ordered the spare ribs & chicken versions to go for our flight home. Would've gone with the pork patty w/ preserved fish as well, but not everyone appreciates the aroma and goodness of this dish.

If you're in SF, please go! Set your judgments aside and enjoy the old-style charm and the food! 


*Hostess is used very loosely here. You pretty much have to fight for survival once you're seated.
author: Lily C.

description: Authentic canto style dim sum, best spare ribs and salted fish steamed over rice. The location was a bit of hole in the wall but so worth it. Great price and quality, will return.
author: Yayan L.

description: Basics apply here. Yes, it is economical. Early in the morning it's full of local business men and retirees from the apartment towers nearby. Black bean sauce pork ribs with rice is the overwhelming favorite: so good! The hot chili oil is very flavorful. What else, besides tea, could one possibly need? As the day winds forward, items appear in the display shelves. Example: I cannot describe how wonderful the cha-su (BBQ pork) in puff pastry is when they bring it out. So.good.and.so.cheap.
author: J.Fred D.

description: Definitely authentic and bare bones. We were confused by the system since many regulars go into the kitchen and get their own plates and tea. We waited and eventually the waitress brought out a cart stacked high with steam pans and we grabbed what we could. Turns out, many of the buns are at the front counter and you need to ask the waitress or go up and get those. We got the wrong sparerib dish-it was greasy and tasteless. The beef dumplings and shrimp dumplings were good and the BBQ pork buns were unbelievable. We got two of those to go after devouring the first order. Two people stuff for $20 total, including a small tip.
author: Dawn L.

description: The siewmai and the shrimp har gao were really delicious! The black bean ribs over rice is sooooo tasty. The chicken feet was good too. The rice crepe w shrimps is not the best one i've had, the crepe was too sticky and a bit thick. The food came quickly. Dont expect it to be a nice neat clean place becos it's not. But for the price it's great value for money and they serve great food!
author: Thuy T.

description:
The dim sum here was good quality. Had shrimp shumai, chicken feet, and some other items. 

The only concern I had was that the cart didnt come by as often as I would like. The servers were nice and polite as far as things go. 

Finding parking was not pleasant but that is common for the area. There was a bus stop right in front of the place so if you use public transportation, you are in luck.
author: Tiffany P.

description:
San Francisco's Chinatown, the largest outside of Asia, provides streets of restaurants, grocery stores, and shops for a whole afternoon of fun. Which is exactly what we did.

Roaming around the streets trying to find a dim sum place for Sunday lunch, we crammed ourselves in with other locals (and tourists!). Dried goods line almost every grocery store, fresh produce just right beside, and the smell of BBQ pork everywhere!

We ended up finding Dol Ho, a small dim sum restaurant that offered to go items. Definitely a hole in the wall place, with minimal seating but packed to the brim with locals aside from one group of confused tourists seated communally with a group of seniors. As we entered, we increased the tourist count, and likewise, were seated with a couple of elderly ladies, happily chatting away and eating a bowl of rice and spare ribs.

When we were seated, we quickly became confused as well. Items coming in from the back kitchen were lost in translation as none of the servers could speak English! Although we're both Asian and had a rough idea of what we wanted to eat, we had to go with the tried and true method of "look, point, and eat." Time to experiment! Our first dish: a shrimp batter nested inside sliced eggplants. Normally not a fan of eggplant, this dish was actually well done. The shrimp batter was nice and light and the eggplant added quite a bit of substance to the dish. It surprisingly held its shape during the preparation and wasn't mushy at all, contrary to a lot of eggplant dishes that I had tried.

Our usual dishes started to roll out at this point: dumplings! The traditional pork siu mai dumpling, along with variations of shrimp and vegetable dumplings. Delicious! The couple sharing our table smiled at our selections and nudged the soy sauce and chili condiments towards us. Not that it required any of it, as they were all well seasoned.

By the time we finished our dumplings, we were in a bit of a lull. Not knowing what else to order from the carts and definitely craving to try something other than dumplings, we waited. When a different cart pulled up, our chatting tablemates pointed to a steamed rice and pork dish that they previously shared. Taking the cue, we nodded and tried it out. Pretty good! And although I had no idea what the pricing was on any of these dishes, I imagined this was the cheapest because it was not a seafood dish. Bang for your buck? Knowing the elderly Asian population, that's probably why they urged us to try it. It filled the rest of our bellies up and we called it a day!

My thoughts? Although not your tourist trap, and trust me, we saw them along the streets, Don Ho ended up being pretty decent dim sum. It's nothing particularly special, just some home-style cooked food, freshly steamed dumplings, and a chance to try new dishes at the suggestion of your new San Francisco friends. The price? For the two of us, it ended up being a tad less than $20. Bonus! No wonder the two women shared a rice bowl and left smiling!

Washing down our dim sum eats, which can be a heavier lunch than most, I opted for some guava bubble tea down the street. A nice relaxing day! Highly suggested if you've finished your tour of the Wharf and the piers and want to check out what else San Francisco has to offer.
author: Cindy N.

description:
The food was ok and service was ok.  The food was better than the service.  Don' know if I would try this place again.  Typical dim sum, but we were the only non-Asians here.  

Lack of seating and this place was busy from beginning to end.  I would try this place again, but not before trying all the other places.

P.s.  The bathroom was clean, but it was weird...you have to walk through the kitchen to get there.
author: Heidi H.

description: Great! Excellent shrimp dumplings
author: Jeremy A.

description: No frills and legit. By no frills, I mean there will be old grandpas coughing loudly and rustling newspapers while you chopstick pick your way through delicious food served on mixed and matched dishes.  The food is good and fast.  I strongly advise that if you come, bring someone who knows the name of dishes and that everyone in the group is cool with hole in the wall places. I can imagine a tourist giving a bad review if this were one of their first dim sum experiences, bring them to a "cha lau" restaurant with decor, waiters in vests, and dim sum carts instead.
author: Siu L.

description: Solid Dim Sum, service is decent and workers speak little English. But authentic place in China town, I'd come again.
author: Ross S.

description:
This is the place favoured by old people who like blackbean spareribs and rice. It can get noisy, and the staff may seem a little frazzled by lunch time, but this tea house is serious business. Real and down to earth. Good food. 

They've been around a long time and know what they're doing.
author: John F.

description:
Hole in the wall place in Chinatown. Please do not come here if you are afraid of bad service and needs a 4 star restaurant. I will be up front with you, you don't feel like this is a clean place when you walk in. You will mainly see old folks who will sit there with the spare ribs over rice(those silver looking bowls) and their newspaper. You will also walk in and notice there is a big crowd on your left.(don't worry, most of them are taking food to go) And be ready to wait for about 5 minutes without anyone coming to greet you. So if you don't mind any of that and do care for some good food with AMAZING hot sauce(not really spicy, it's the flavor), then please come try Dol Ho.

Food: You should DEFINITELY get the spare ribs over rice. Almost every table will order at least one of these. They also have a great variety of fried deliciousness like fried shrimp balls. I've tried their shrimp dumplings(Ha Gaw), all I can say is I definitely had better. But whatever you eat, please try their hot sauce!! It'd nothing like you thought it'd be. They put a lot of stuff in it and it taste great! 

WARNING-- you might not want to use the bathroom here. You will have to walk through the kitchen and you will most likely not have a good time. 

Overall, if I did not scare you and want to have a "chinatown experience", give this place a try!
author: Sappho C.

description: If you like dim sum and are on a budget, this the right place.  All locals and Chinese tourists.  We liked everything we tried and lunch for 2 was twenty bucks.
author: Cris F.

description:
There are numerous hole in the wall dim sum places in chinatown. On yelp if you do a search you see the famous ones like Good Mong Kok bakery. Why is this place not at the top? My family comes to the city about once or twice a year and I never knew this place was here. What a pleasant surprise! We just bought some deep fried meat dumplings and fried taro root dumplings to-go. We ate them in our car about 10 minutes later. It was cold, but my husband said it was the most delicious ones he's had even when it's cold, it's better than the hot ones in other places. And this place actually have quite a few tables to sit down! Too bad our trip was quite short this time. I look forward to going back to eat at the restaurant next time.

It's not a 5-star because it's a hole in the wall place. But if you just want great and cheap food, this is it.
author: M R.

description: A small, 25 year old, locals hang out for dim sum.  Very reasonably priced, cash only.  Traditional Cantonese dishes only, no fancy creations.  Good solid dim sum, but language may be a problem.
author: John J O.

description:
I absolutely enjoy eating dim sum from this place. I really like how fresh their food is. Some of the dishes I enjoy eating are the shrimp and pork dumplings along with the shrimp rice rolls splattered with soy sauce. The staff here are knowledgeable, friendly and courteous. I'm still loving their spare ribs rice plate, sometimes I come here to order these rice plates to go when I don't feel like cooking dinner.

Wi-Fi:
The Wi-Fi signals in this area aren't very clear since it is SFHAwifi. Want clear Wi-Fi signals? I suggest going to the library or Quickly on 1135 Powell St and 1170 Powell St.

Payment: CASH ONLY!

Parking: Mostly Street  and Metered Parking

I suggest parking your car at Portsmouth Square, North Beach or Vallejo St Garage if you plan on driving here. It's very nice if you can find yourself a spot to park your car. Be prepared to have spare coins or an SFMTA parking meter debit card with you since most of the spots here are equipped with parking meters. The DPT staff can appear anytime in those carts, via bicycle or by walking through this area.

Their Business Hours were originally from 8 am - 3 pm Monday-Tuesday and Thursday-Sunday but they are probably revising their Hours of Operation or something.
author: Bennett W.

description: Food excellent. But they were out of 50% of the items on the menu and they said it was too busy to push the cart around - we were hoping for that experience :0(  Busy and service spotty but obviously popular with the natives - no English spoken here.  Cash ONLY!  Walk through the kitchen to get to the bathroom. Rat traps everywhere in there. No toilet paper.
author: Kimberly N.

description:
Knocking around the big city and got a hankering for some dim sum.  Stumbled across this place and loved it.  It is somewhat small and crowded but the food is great.  Better than most and priced on the cheap side.  Been to other dim sum places that are bigger, fancier and higher priced and definately not as good.  

"Typical" dim sum with the carts that roll around.  English is definately a second language there, so bruch up on your manderin.
author: Jeff G.

description: This place is a small hole in the wall lined with small tables packed with people which is a good sign. We were lucky enough to be able to grab a table since a large group just left before us. Love the fact that the have a big ol containers of hot chili oil already at the tables so you dont have to keep bugging the servers for more. Everything is served piping hot straight out of the kitchen on the traditional dim sum cart just like how it should be. The dim sum here is absolutely amazing because its super fresh nothings been sitting around in their steamer containers. They pack up all the cold dim sum that no ones ordered and sell it at the counter in front of the window. Everything was super good but my personal favorites where the shrimp and cilantro dumplings and the shu mai. The chicken feet were by far the best I've had since moving to the Bay Area here. No frills good dim sum for super cheap. To feed 7 people cost under 70 bucks! What a steal! Will def be finding our way back here soon.
author: Mercedes R.

description: Kind of a hole in a wall, you aren't here for service or cleanliest, food is mediocre at best. They push dim sim plates out on carts and you get to pick your items without having to order. My sisters liked the Siu Mai, Pai Quat and har chueng the most. We were actually on a mission to find the best mini egg custard filled buns only to find they sell gigantic ones, I bought one anyways and thought the bun was good but the custard was too artificial and sweet tasting.
author: Darling M.

description:
This place is by no means amazing but it is great for cheap Chinese food. My mom loves this place and she is a pretty picky Chinese eater. She loves their spare ribs over rice bowls. I don't like spare ribs but everyone else seems to love it. It is cheap and hearty! If you have a regular size stomach one bowl of that and an item of dim sum is enough to last you the rest of the day. Probably cost you 5 bucks including tip! WHOA! 

Sometimes it is a hit or miss though. My mom said they got rotten shrimp before. The shrimp today was fine. They have stuff you don't find at legit dim sum restaurants. You don't have to eat here. They are more like a fast food joint. A lot of people order to go.
author: Sarah C.

description: Excellent food. First-timers may be slightly uncomfortable - I had a Canto speaker with me to take care of ordering - but service is friendly and expedient (again, first-timers may be off put, but don't confuse expedience with being rude or standoffish -- the waitresses are very busy!)
author: Alice J.

description: Very basic  dimsum place and the servers were very nice. They brought the shrimp dishes when they felt that we were going to order the seafood dimsum. I also requested the tofu dimsum which was quite greasy and not that fluffy. It was an interesting dimsum experience but I had super great company. Each dimsum entree was approximately $2.50. We had the shrimp balls, crispy shrimp balls, pork shamai, tofu with shrimp, and hot tea. We were the only nonChinese in the restaurant that Sunday.The dimsum was sort of salty as well.
author: Kitty D.

description:
IMPORTANT: First of all, if you are not of (South) Chinese descent, you will have a different experience than me and maybe should disregard this review as it will be biased but if that doesn't bother you then keep reading! 
*not biased paragraph

Chinese name: 多好茶室 

This has got to be one of the best places in the City and Chinatown which is not saying much because most of them are alright, bordering on gross. This place serves comfort food more than anything else (although I only tried spareribs over rice and steamed salted fish & pork paste over rice). I think anything over rice is basically comfort food lol. I wonder how I've never been to this place; it's so good! We ordered 2 (orders of) fung zao [chicken feet], 2 siu mai, 2 nu mai gai [sweet rice with chicken] (jumbo size!), 2 ha gao, 2 chiang foon [rolled rice noodle], 2 pai goo't fan [spareribs over rice], and 1 ham ngui ji fan [salted fish & pork paste over rice]. Probably the best 'Mom n Pops' place I've ever been to. 

I came here with my grandma and 3 of my aunts so they did all the ordering for us. They also didn't give a menu (probably assuming we know what we can order, which is correct) but I basically memorized all the basic dim sum items I really like. The staff was really helpful when I spilled my whole cup of tea on the table which was embarrassing to say the least. I'd say you can't go wrong with any dishes they serve because it got the rural mainland China taste. Kind of hard to come by outside of China.

*They serve their stuff (dim sum included) in metal so don't be too surprised if it's really hot. The plates and tea cups are ceramic. They also have soy sauce and the spicy mix that's served in most Asian restaurants, which is the bomb diggity even though it looks weird. I saw in one of the reviews for this restaurant that the customer was complaining that the spareribs have tiny bones. Well duh, this is Chinese cuisine, not the [awful] American Chinese stuff so take that into account if/when you eat here.
author: Victoria H.

description:
The definition of the hole in the wall restaurant. Unlike some of the other reviewed Yelp restaurants nearby that have no seating, this is a real restaurant. 

Spartan to be sure but the food that comes out of the kitchen is fantastic. Someone else recommended sitting by the kitchen since the single cart that comes out needs to make the rounds of the whole place. 

We feasted and had two beers to boot and the bill was $21. Oh yeah.
author: Mark T.

description: I just read this place had a food safety warning, but to hell with that.  The Dim Sum here is fantastic.  What is life without a little bit of danger amiright?  It's cheap, its delicious, it has zero ambiance, and there is nothing wrong with any of that.  P.S. I ate here with three people and none of us got sick.
author: Enrique F.

description:
MUST-TRY, especially if you're foreign to yum-cha.

I have been having Sunday morning yum-cha's since I was 0. I know what good dim sum tastes like. And this is good dim sum! It deserves so much more credit, although I do admit it is hard when they are so small so it always looks super-filled and kind of intimidating in a weird way. I used to be embarrassed to come here with my family because it was so cramped, and I would be all "why don't we just go to New Asia" or somewhere basic. But this place is yummy AND cheap. 

It is a true hole-in-the-wall gem.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
First off: dirty dirty. This place was not clean and it seems like a long time since it was cleaned. 

after combing yelp for a great Dim Sum I landed on Dol Ho. It seemed like it would be great. Authentic, no tourists. Food right from China. 

The place was packed with all Chinese. It was very busy. I felt like no one spoke English. I thought it was cool and novel until I tried to order. Ugh. They just brought me stuff which I didn't know what it was. I kinda lost confidence in whether the undercooked chicken was cooked at all. Actually it could of been fine but I was kinda grossed out by the experience. 

They showed me to a small table that was being used by an old Chinese man I sat across from him and he was very nice. He tried to help but the language barrier was too great. 

I don't recommend.
author: J K.

description:
3.5 stars!

Unless you're with a friend that speaks Chinese... it's a little hard to order. There's only one server and she is very intimidating haha. Overall, nice vibe in the restaurant. Seems like a lot of local people come over and eat. The food was 3.5 stars.. Not warm enough and some were overly greasy. But all plates were reasonable good and very large portion! I might come back to get some other menus.
author: Sue K.

description: OMG, where to start? Well, first, while I'm an eclectic white boy, and while my wife is an eclectic Filipina, we are definitely familiar with the dim sum offerings in LA's Chinatown. Having said that, San Francisco's Chinatown is at least ten times larger, and far more bustling. On the recommendations of Yelpers, we gave "Dol Ho" a try. And we're sure glad we did! This precious hole-in-the-wall is the real deal. Authentic to the core. And don't worry at all if you aren't Chinese and don't speak a word of Chinese. We had perfectly fine service, and language was no barrier at all. Point and you shall receive! The total tab for two very satiated diners: $21.25. The best dim sum experience of my life. Damned good! Can't wait to return on my next voyage to The City. This place was incredible.
author: Mark C.

description: Great dim sum experience and my favorite is steamed spare rib. The waitress are always busy and can be unresponsive from time to time, but considering its price($40 including tax and tips for 4), it is a pretty good deal.
author: Vicky L.

description: Oh yeah, easy like Sunday morning, ordered the shrimp balls and fried tofu. Still waiting on the beef patty as we walked in at 0737. The place was 90% packed already as everyone was just sipping tea.
author: Kevin L.

description: 3.5 stars. Dingy hole in the wall with tattered awning, we were the only non- Asians in the place.  I liked it!  Good shrimp balls, sesame balls, my favorite was a shrimp & parsley steamed dumpling.  Somewhat limited selection.  I really wanted some greens though, the only vegetable I saw was a green bell pepper.
author: Art-Suzanne R.

description: The food here is pretty good and reasonably priced. I like the fact that they bring the food out in carts although they only had 1 cart out at a time, and there was a 5 min wait between carts. This place gets really busy on the weekends, they don't lead you to your table, you have to just take a table when it frees up. As a result you have to be aggressive when taking a table or else someone will cut in front of you and take your table.
author: Guorui W.

description: Excellent dim sum. Clearly appreciated by the locals, as this place was packed soon after I arrived.
author: David G.

description:
Food was decent, no wait when i came at 9:30ish. 
Price is not bad, everything ranges from 2.75 - 3.75
For two people, we ended up spending $19. 
The steamed rice and pork square was very delish.
Compared to Good Mong Kok though, the hai gow and siu mai's aren't as big.
author: Janice C.

description: The shrimp dumpling (har gao) here are stellar. Thin skins (unlike the overly stuffed gummy ones at Good Mong Kok) and nice filling. The shiu mai I wasn't as big of a fan of because it erred strongly on the meatier side. Shrimp dumplings with cilantro are exactly that and very similar to the shrimp dumplings so just pick one of them to get. Prices are reasonable and if you get it to go, it's cheaper than if you eat it there.
author: Jenny W.

description:
That little place reminds me of the Hong Kong old style tea house where the locals goes to every morning for breakfast and tea. The older folks would sit around reading the morning paper while some catch up with their friends in between their market time. Many people stream in and out of the café to buy take-away breakfast.

We sat by a table near the entrance and watched the on going action in the café while enjoying our dim sum and tea. 

The one word I can describe the dim sum in this café is 'down-to-earth'. No frills, a hole-in-the-wall place where you rub elbows with the locals. As we sat down the hostess promptly delivered a hot pot of Chinese tea and the freshly prepared dim sum varieties on a cart. 

The dumpling was steaming hot as I bite into it. I can taste the freshness of the meat and shrimp, no MSG and somehow the texture was not oily like most dim sum does. Not that I mind if the dim sum is oily since I love eating fat. But I guess that's what most people would like. It was delicious!

We enjoy eating the 3 different types of steamed dumplings and decided to try a bake item. I picked the BBQ pork pastry puff. When the plate landed on our table, my first impression was the puff was too big. I begin to imagine the texture to be thick and firm with very little BBQ pork fillings in it.

As I break open one into half with a pair of chopsticks, the whole puff fell apart easily. The pastry was thin and soft, and filled with plenty of BBQ pork cube fillings. I took a bite. The BBQ pork was not too sweet and the pastry just melts in the mouth.

It was one of the best tasting BBQ pork puff I ever had. If I want to burn my carb count for the once in a while treats, this could be it. I estimate it to have about 15g of carb per puff.
author: Kelly P.

description:
I live in North Beach and I've been eating at this place for a couple of years. I love it because they serve old school steamed bar-b-que pork buns from the '80s and nobody else does and they taste awesome. 

Lately, I've been ordering two orders of shrimp dumplings with vegetables and a bar-b-que pork bun to go for 5$. 

Beware the bones in the ribs rice. Beef rice is an awesome choice. It's a big old meat ball with rice and a nice soy sauce. It doesn't have bones and it's a serious lunch for about 5$ or less--with tea if ate in.
author: Avram K.

description: Even better than i thought it would be.  A total hole in the wall place with delicious food. Very satisfying.
author: Josh B.

description: The food is inexpensive. The service sub-par, but you get what you pay for.
author: Sherman C.

description:
Dol Ho is no lavish Yank Sing but if you want legit Dim Sum this is the real deal. If it's not in the carts you can ask for it to be made fresh. Yes you might have to share a table with a stranger but that's part of the experience. 

The spare ribs over rice is perfection! Apparently you can ask buy a bag of the pre-marinated raw ribs to make this at home. One bag costs around 4.25 and enough to make 4 servings of the little bowls or 1 family size bowl.
author: elle f.

description:
Went to this place to try their dim sum on our recent visit to San Francisco.  This place is absolutely ridiculously CHEAP!  One of the cheapest places I've ever had dim sum at (I've gone all my life as I'm asian).  There were three of us and we ordered 8 dishes - total was $24 after tip. Ridiculous. Oh how I wish I lived in San Francisco.

Anyways, as people have previously said, the place is hole in the wall but it's not really dirty. It's essentially your typical asian restaurant - very bare and minimal.  We came here on a weekday around 1pm so we probably missed the lunch rush but there were still lots of old asian grandma's/grandpa's.  Looks like they constantly come here all the time.  We did see one caucasian couple and the person in the front was nice enough to help them order (think she may be the only one that speaks english).

For the food, we ordered regular dishes that we normally get when we go for dim sum (har gow, siu mai are staples). There was 4 of them per dish which was nice! We also tried the har cheung fun (shrimp rice noodle rolls), their famous pai gwut fan (rice with spare ribs), shrimp fried balls and the wu gock (taro dumplings/balls), the last two dishes came in 3's and were enormous.  We also tried two other dishes, not sure of their names but they were steamed dumplings with shrimp and pork.  The only bad dish we had was the wu gock as it was cold.  Food is a bit on the salty side but that's what hot tea is for! Haha, the best was my dad went into the back to re-fill our tea. We'd fit in perfectly with the locals!

Parking is INSANE.  One thing I would definitely recommend for tourists is to park at the Portsmouth Square (it's underground parking for $3/hr which is reasonable). The address is: 733 Kearny Street, write it down and put it in the GPS.  Trust me on this, you'll save lots of time and headaches of trying to look for street parking which is ridiculous with the hills and constant people crossing the street.  If you do street parking, there is the ones with yellow parking meters (only for 30 minutes max) vs. black meters (1 hour parking max) although maybe you'll get lucky and find 2 hours?

Anyways, I know there are lots of places to get dim sum in San Francisco but if you want something cheap and good, this is a good bet. Make sure you bring CASH as that's all they accept.
author: Jonny M.

description: One of the better Dim Sum spots. Hygiene is questionable as the tables stay oily and banged up but the food is good. We went during lunch and got the assorted trays of Dim Sum portions delivered to our table. Most of the dishes I expected and enjoyed (Chicken Feet, Shui Mai, Har Gow, Meatballs, etc), some were new and weird (Bell Pepper Meatballs, Taro And Pork Noodle Beds, etc). Overall, it was a good quick bite to eat
author: Alex K.

description: We scraped the bottom of the barrel and it was so damn delicious!!!!!!! I wish we had more dim sum to eat but unfortunately, we came at 4:00pm and the dim sum was basically out, but we still managed to eat some shrimps and buns. Best experiences of my dim sum life. Will be back if we're in SF!
author: Loan-Anh T.

description:
Do you like cheap dim sum any day of the week?  Do you like when they bring around the little carts & you try to figure out what's in each of the dishes?  Do you like eating in dingy restaurants where you may be literally rubbing elbows with older Chinese folks?  Then Dol Ho is for you!

This is your typical divey, no frills, hole in the wall Chinatown restaurant.  The servers are loud & not terribly friendly.  The food is cheap, but it's very good.  I would recommend the shrimp har gow.  It was the best I've ever had!  It tasted very fresh & melted in my mouth.  The shrimp & chive dumplings and pork shu mai were also delicious.  It seems like everyone in the restaurant was eating the spare ribs over rice but when it came around on the cart it looked like a pile of raw meat.  Not very appetizing so we skipped it, but it seems like this is the most popular dish in the restaurant so obviously there must be something good about it.

The only disappointment for me was the lack of vegetable dishes.  I asked for an order of Chinese broccoli & was handed a dim sum menu with no vegetable options.  Strange.  Don't come here if you are a vegetarian!

We left more than satisfied and paid a measly $20 for lunch for 3 people.
author: Erin S.

description: Poor service, some food are cold and not fresh. Bad experience for Chinese dim sum.  Do not choose this one,same price you will have better choice.
author: Zoey L.

description:
Everytime i walk by dol Ho i always are plenty of old grandmas and grandpas inside eating little pots of black bean spareribs with rice. 

The black bean spareribs with rice is cheap! At $2.50 a bowl, no wonder all the grandmas and grandpas come here for lunch. Dol Ho also has giant beef balls that are unlike any you'll find at a dim sum place. And their crispy shrimp balls are to die for! Each order comes with 4 pieces so there's plenty to go around.
author: Jess s.

description:
Don't let the faded awning fool you, this place makes the best deep fried savory dumplings (ham sui gok). They also have the sweet kind that's filled with some kind of sweet bean filling. I only like the savory kind, but both varieties are fried to a crisp, golden brown. So delicious! These aren't like those limp, greasy fried dumplings that you find at other dim sum places; I tell you they can hold their ground. The sweet sesame ones stay perfectly round even if you let them sit around. That's how crispy they are! At 55 cents a pop, these are a steal! Whenever I find myself in Chinatown, which is rare, I make it a point to stop here! 

Btw, the ladies who work behind the counter are rude, but that comes with the territory.
author: Audrey T.

description: Amazing dim sum, great spare ribs, pork dumpling, shrimp dumpling, shrimp crepe, tea is amazing. Came in a party of 6 and had a visitor from Singapore also. Love the service and food.
author: Jonathan A.

description:
Disappointing.  Any dim sum in Chinatown should be held to higher standards than the unfortunate offerings that Dol Ho provides.  I've always considered midwest and east coast dim sum to be inferior to what we can get in California, but I can definitely say that you can get better dim sum in St. Louis or Salt Lake than what they serve up at Dol Ho.

While the restaurant was nearly packed, the food was generally bland and mushy, the tables and plates were sticky, and the service was, well, let's just say that it wasn't really provided.  The char siu bao, which is always my favorite, was one of the worst dishes we ordered; I couldn't even tell if there was any actual meat in it, since there was just some not-quite-char-siu-flavored goop inside.

I'm used to the different standards of Chinatown businesses, but at the very least, the food has to be good.  And it wasn't!  I'm going elsewhere next time.
author: Chris Y.

description:
This is my favorite place to eat in Chinatown. I love the pork spare ribs over rice. 

It's really hole-in-the-wall and run by older Chinese people so don't expect to receive great customer service, but if you can come with someone who speaks Cantonese it really helps. Even if you don't speak Chinese, it's worth a visit just for the ribs!

TIP:  I buy the pre-marinated bags of pork ribs they sell and freeze them when I get home. When I'm craving spare ribs, I defrost a bag in my fridge and cook them over rice in my rice cooker. I literally just pour the whole bag of meat over the rice and press cook. It turns out great and it's delicious!
author: Phoebe Y.

description: The food is awesome... All shrimp dumplings were so fresh, the "crepe" with Chinese parsley was delicious. Stuffed eggplant was also yum. However, the service is terrible - we had to make a scene to get someone to take our order, and every time we ordered something they acted like it was a huge imposition.
author: Ro A.

description:
If you are not concerned about fancy atmosphere or decor, don't care too much about the service, but want to experience the true offerings of what Chinatown has, i.e., good, tasty dim sum, this is the place to come to.

Dol Ho seems to cater to locals more than tourists. There were lots of elderly folk enjoying a couple of dishes and a pot of tea. We ordered steamed chicken over rice, shumai, har gow, eggplant stuffed with shrimp, pork and mushroom dumpling, turnip cake, chicken wrapped in rice sheet, beef wrapped in rice sheet, steamed chicken feet. Nice portions, more than enough food for everyone. Don't bother asking for veggies - no gai lan here. 

Theirs is definitely comfort food. Prices are outrageously reasonable - our tab for four including a generous tip, came to $30. 

I would definitely make my way back to Dol Ho on my next trek into the City!
author: IM M.

description: We went to this place because of the yelp reviews. It has great food and is very cheap. Fed 3 people fully for $24 on a weekend. The place on the outside looks horrible but the kitchen is clean (large door by seating area that you can easily see inside). Totally worth it. Don't bother going to a large place, go to the hole in the wall. :)
author: Megan V.

description: Tasty dim sum takeout.  If you're not familiar with this kind of authentic Chinese food experience, you may take it to be a bit lacking in service, but I say, it adds to it's charm.  Crowded at times.  Go with someone who speaks Cantonese, if you can.
author: Kev M.

description:
Walk in. Look around. Find a table by a Chinese granny. And order what she does. They are the ones with sage wisdom at Dol Ho and know what's good. 

I've walked by Dol Ho so many times but never thought too much it until I had a friend visiting and he wanted a more "authentic" dim sum experience than City View and Yank Sing. Thanks to Yelp, we ventured in to this modest nook that serves fresh and cheap afternoon delights. 

We had the mandatory spareribs over rice that was so raved about (and next-table-granny gestured us to order it too). It was alright - the spareribs had good flavor and were tender but overall nothing that special. I think the standout for us was the radish cake. It had a great consistency and a nice crispiness around it. Other dishes we tried included the staples - Siu Mai (pork dumpling), Har Gow (Shrimp Dumpling), Har Cheong (Shrimp in rice noodles) and fried Yong Tau Foo (Minced shrimp stuffed in tofu). They were all decent and satisfied our Dim Sum fix although I found myself reaching over aforementioned Granny's table to get more chili sauce. 

I think the real charm to Dol Ho is it's lack of pretension, take-it-or-leave it, just-for-the-townies experience. That and the price is hard to beat. Our total was less than $10 a person and we were quite full I must say. For simple, unadulterated fare in a setting that matches just that, Dol Ho is worth at least a visit.
author: Jon L.

description: Went here on a whim when a friend came to visit and we really lucked out! Great dim sum for a very cheap price. We ordered about 8 dishes to share and cost $25. The only thing I would caution is that if you don't speak Chinese it's hard to order. But the servers are great and if you ask them to open up the dim sum before you order, they will. Also, you have to ask them about the steamed pork buns if you want an order and they will get them from you. Overall ambiance is okay. It's pretty clean but pretty basic. Don't go here if you want a fancy sit down restaurant, but if you want a quick fix of delicious dim sum, this place does the job. Also, be aggressive and just sit down at the first available table. Otherwise, it can get to be a long wait.
author: Viroopa V.

description: Let me be as straightforward as possible. Don't have high expectations for this place. If you want cheap dim sum this is the place. When you walk in, it's literally looks like a shack, just basic table and chairs. Even though this place doesn't have a wait, it's very limited seating and you most likely have to share your table. When we were seated there was a guy sitting there eating quietly by himself and the other side of the table still had the empty plates from the previous guests. You just have to push it aside and someone will clean the table off. You have to be aggressive to get service here, like previous reviewers, it's normal to walk to the back and get your own tea.
