There is only one cart that comes around with different items every 15 minutes or so. Make sure you get their attention, they also don't speak much English. The best food was the short ribs over rice. Other than that, the rest of the items weren't as memorable. I feel the major turnoff of this place is the cleanliness and unconventional setup of sharing tables. If you're willing to be open minded and not picky about its appearance, this could be for you.
author: Van N.

description: We tried this place today on the Yelp reviews.  It's a true hole in the wall.  They were out of most of the things we wanted to order and the waitress ended up just bringing us a tray of random things and handing them to us.  The tea was delicious.  The sticky rice/meat item wrapped in a banana leaf was good, some sort of beef meatball looking thing was terrible.  I'm giving it two stars because the place was filthy.
author: Stacey J.

description: One of the best dim sum my boyfriend and I ever had. You don't even need soy sauce on the siumai. That good. We had 6+ orders, and it came up to $18.79!!!! We felt out of place because almost all the customers there are Chinese, which was a good sign for us; that means the food is good. Props to Thrillist for getting us here.
author: Diane D.

description:
Great chili oil!  Hau gau was full of shrimp.  Siu mai so so.  Loved the beef fun.  Came too early for the spareribs but when they came out the waitress put them on all the "regulars" tables -- the Asian men reading newspapers.

Had some trouble ordering but can't beat the prices.
author: E. L.

description: Dim sum was really good. Got a little bit of everything, and everything was pretty good and flavorful!
author: Ben Z.

description:
I absolutely love this place. I grew up going to Chinatown every weekend with my family and my Grandma would always buy us a to-go order of their spare rib over rice or their beef balls over rice. It's just the right amount of food and it's so cheap! I love the spare rib sauce they pour over the rice and if you eat it right away, you'll notice that the rice is cooked really well. I would eat here everyday if I worked near. 

The rest if their dim sum is pretty cheap too. The best part is that its authentic. I'd recommend the thick rice noodles over beef or shrimp. 

Yum. Ok I'm hungry now.
author: Rosie W.

description:
Once you see the decor (and lack of tablecloths) at this place, then you know that you're not going to get 1) good "service" and 2) very very clean tables and dining ware.

With that said, the dim sum was delicious and it came out so fast that I was full about 5 minutes into eating! And everything was so cheap that our bill for 6 items was less than $13. Can you believe that? I don't think I can get dim sum that cheap on this side of the Bay!

If I'm ever in the area again, I'll definitely stop by this place. =]
author: Diana T.

description:
Solid HK style dim sum.  Not the best place for those only used to "American Chinese" and there is very little in the way of service there.  However, the food is superb - be clear and respectful to get what you want.  If you have a hard time ordering this isn't the place for you.

Good steamed buns, pork spare ribs, and dumplings.
author: C D.

description:
If you are used to Hong Kong style food places where the place is not exactly as clean as tidy as most of the restaurants in the US, I'd recommend you to give this a try.  It wasn't really crowded when we got there, but we had to share a table with strangers  (this is very usual in HK). 

Most of their dimsum are really good.
author: Archie L.

description: Absolutely great place. Here you can eat Dim Sum like in Hong Kong! Love it!! Come here every Sunday. And it's really cheap, two people can eat here for $15!
author: Cathrine A.

description:
They added salted fish pork patty over rice to their selection!  This is soul food at its best.  You don't get a lot of salted fish but the aroma and flavor are definitely there.  The pork patty is tender and flavorful too.  

We came here late around 2pm and there were no crowds and we had plenty tables to choose from.  Instead of the 3 carts (rice, steamed items and fried items), you order what you want and it's steamed for you.  We had shrimp rice noodle (ok), sparerib (delicious, this is a must), beef ball (again, another must), beef tripe (very nice garlic flavor), and cilantro shrimp dumpling (tasty).  All this and 3 rice to go (one each of sparerib, chicken and the salted fish pork patty) for a little over $20!
author: Gloria H.

description: This has got to be one of the funniest dim sum restaurants I have been to. The quality is decent for the price you pay. It is no upscale restaurant, more run down than anything. We came here knowing what to expect after reading the reviews so we were just anticipating some decent dim sum and we got that. The service was quick. The server doesn't know much English. There is no menu given unless you ask for it and I think its just their items on an 8x11 piece of paper with no price. They reuse this piece of paper fairly often too. Every time our order came out, instead of marking the item on the sheet, she would just pull out another used sheet which had the designated amount of dishes that came out. It was hilarious. There are a lot of the older local Chinese gramps sitting around in this restaurant as well, but a lot of other locals dropping in to pick up take out.
author: Emy A.

description:
In the heard of Chinatown, next to the busy markets on Stockton where everyone is selecting the best and fresh produce.  In between Pacific and Stockton street there is Dol Ho!  In front you can barely see the inside because of the large tray's that are steaming to keep the buns warm.

This place is full of senior citizens and old folks from around and far.  Mostly just having Dim sum and enjoying tea.  In translation of Dim Sum to Chinese, it refers to drink tea.  Majority of the folks here are reading the newspaper and  having small bites of their food.

Usually one or two people run a cart of food.  The first cart usually is a variety of Dim Sum.  Har Gow, Shu Mai, Fung jao etc.. From shrimp to park dumplings to the delicate of chicken feet.  A lot to choose from and cheap.  Then another cart rolls out with these stainless steel pots full of goodies.  Spare rib over rice or pork cake over rice.  This is the entree of this place, famous for their spare rib over rice.

A small stainless tall bowl will surprisingly fill you up easy.  At $2.75 a pop is fair game and enough to fill you up.  Majority of the time its a self service place here.  All the folks who finish their hot water in their tea pot will go self service to refill hot water because the people working here are busy.  Right, i know bad customer service? It's a tradition and the people who enjoy coming here don't mind and just want to get more water and enjoy more tea and eat.

Overall this is a family run business, over decades literally.  Still the same good stuff and hope this place will stay open forever.  Everyone always order the spare rib over rice.  People order more than one order of this goodie.  They also sell raw spare ribs marinade and ready to steam at home.  They sell it by the zip lock bag.  

This place is a hole in a wall and great.  This place have so many regulars that if there is a chair open and table half empty someone will sit across or next to you so they can enjoy their food and not have to wait.

**parking**

This will be tough, best bet park far or park in the parking structure at Portsmouth square or Vallejo street garage.

CASH ONLY CASH ONLY CASH ONLYCASH ONLY CASH ONLY CASH
author: Kenneth Y.

description: Hole in the wall.  Went here because of the yelp rating which did not live up to the rating of why we went in the first place.  Very difficult to order if you are not Chinese speaking.  Service was terrible and rude, but she was rude to everyone so at least it wasn't because we weren't Chinese (and the only whites in the place).  The food was ok, but not great.  We're from Hawaii so we can get way better dim sum then this place had to offer.  The price was good considering the taste was ok.
author: Lisa D.

description:
It scares me that I'm giving this place a 4 star just because it's a crappy hole in the wall, dirty, smelly Chinese restaurant and yet they have the most delightful $1.50 spare ribs over rice!!  

We came here after our 10k for the Chinatown YMCA run and at first i was REALLY hesitant to eat here.  The crowd, the smells, the service... SIGH.  But, who am I to be such a snob about GOOD FOOD?  There were 8 of us and they happily accommodated our large group when it was pretty obvious that this is usually a solo, max 2 per group type of restaurant.  Yes, expect to be seated on a round table with a bunch of random strangers.  It's that kind of restaurant :)

Overall, a very good experience.  no frills but good and cheap food.  i will be going back the next time I'm in CT!
author: Sandy L.

description:
Chinatown was crazy busy with everyone shopping for Chinese New Year....we had to get off of Stockton! Fortunately, we walked West on Pacific and found this tiny restaurant with lots of locals. We glanced in and as we were standing in the doorway a Chinese gentleman on the sidewalk told us that the food was very good and we should go in. Three stars, not five. Well, we appreciated his advice and went in. Take a seat anywhere. There may not be a menu handy, but they will bring you one.
Our waitress did not speak much English, but would point to an item and say pork or fish or chicken. We could also select off the Chinese/English menu and got BBQ pork buns that were never on her tray. From her tray we selected a chicken with parsley dumpling, a pork dumpling and best by far was the stuffed Egg Plant (unknown fish and shrimp filling). 
We enjoyed our lunch and did not have any second doubts while there, or after our visit. Grand total including hot tea for two.....$11.75.
author: Richard B.

description: This place is a dive of a restaurant and the service is poor, but the food is outstanding.  If you can get past the dirty windows and floors and poor service you will want to eat here everyday. Yes it is that good.... p.s. you do not want to use the restrooms either.  But damn the food is good.
author: Doug G.

description:
whoa, i felt like i was literally in China.

Shared a table with a few strangers and had some delicious pork spare rib over rice. Had an awesome time, but geez does it get packed.
author: dan V.

description:
I usually try to shy away from places like this. It's small, cramped with people, and by the looks of it is hard to talk with the waitstaff unless you know Chinese. Good thing the only bit of Chinese I DO know are the names of dim sum food items. 

Most memorable:
*Spare ribs over rice - comes in a tin can and apparently is what they're known for. Spare ribs laid on rice that's soaked in the rib juices. YUM
*Foil-wrapped chicken - a large piece of chicken on the bone with sauce wrapped in foil and fried that way to cook. Unhealthy but oh sooo good

For a table of 8, it was pretty hard to score a table since there's only one large round table that could accommodate us. But overall, we ended up paying $6/each to be stuffed. Lucky for us, the table was right next to the kitchen and first to be offered food. If you're looking for dim sum in Chinatown, this is a safe bet.

Tips:
Parking is nearly impossible
Wait time can be long if local Chinese are entrenched in the seats
Health score as of Oct 2011 was in the 70s
author: Dennis L.

description:
This place has some of the cheapest good-quality dim sum in town. With a kind of run-down feeling, it can definitely be a little intimidating, especially if you're a first-timer or not familiar with Cantonese. The tables filled with old pau paus and gung gungs (Chinese grandmas and grandpas) should give you an indication of the typical clientele. 

Once you're seated (and be warned, you may be seated with strangers if you have a small party or are by yourself), most usuals get up and grab tea from the back room, as service is minimal here. Pushcarts with ha gao and siu mai come around periodically but when the pai gwut fan, or pork spareribs over rice, comes out, the usuals will run up to the server and take a couple of the silver bowls of goodness. You better be on your toes if you want a chance of eating it cause it seriously goes fast. 

Stop by Dol Ho for an authentic cheap meal. Bring a Cantonese translator if at all possible.  


P.S. Their "lat jiu" or spicy chili oil condiment is RIDICULOUSLY addictive. It's homemade and different from any other lat jiu I've had, with some sort of minced picked veggies in there. I usually buy a jar to keep at home with me...under my pillow.
author: Rayna L.

description:
Went here for a quick bite of dim sum before leaving Chinatown. It's definitely a hole in the wall and we had to compete for attention with people buying stuff for Chinese New Year two days later and with the shouting back and forth from the front counter and the kitchen, but that's part of the charm.

We had shrimp pot stickers, pork dumplings and steamed pork buns all of which were as good as I've had anywhere and the full bill came to less than $8. This is the real deal.

One word of caution is that you should not expect your interactions to be perfectly fluid in English, it took me a few minutes to understand what each thing was and to order the pork buns which didn't get brought out at first.

Even so, if you're even just a little adventurous, you'll love it.
author: Colin D.

description: They are closed at the moment, probably until end of Nov. I wished someone had said something since we went there this morning just for that!
author: Yan Wei L.

description:
This is my favorite dimsum place due to the fact that their dimsum is fairly cheap and portion is pretty generous. I usually just eat their Pork ribs rice and their shrimp dumpling. Any other items are just alright, not my favorite. I think I am happy enough just to eat 1 order of pork ribs rice, especially when they are sizzling hot (yum!). You have to share table with other people and I think only few people there can speak english, and they speak a broken english but they do understand what I am saying.
Best bang for your buck.
author: Andrew T.

description:
This is how it all started.  The Yank Sing, Koi Palace, Cityview, and Yet Wah have all originated from this mom and pop type establishment.  Before the glamor and glory of the fine dining dim sum houses, there was this place, Dol ho.  

Dol ho has been a Chinatown icon since I was growing up and trust me that is a long time ago.  The decor, tables, chairs are probably the ones that were around 40 years ago.  The people serving the food is also the dishwasher, the front counter person, the water refiller.  They do it all.  At one point when I went into the kitchen to refill my teapot.  The employee actually pointed to where the hot water dispenser was as though they were doing me a favor.

I just love the old school places.  This place is not for the faint of heart nor the people who require a certain level of service.  This is just down home Chinese soul food.  The dim sum is good not great but the true feel of  the history of how dim sum houses were is best illustrated in this hole in the wall in Chinatown.
author: jason g.

description:
I was in my mood for something extremely salty and doughy at the same time and since I was in the neighborhood with a friend, I made them wait for me while I rushed inside to grab a few nibblies for our walk back to his apartment.

At the counter, I ordered my usual: puffs with shrimp inside, Har Gow (I'm a sucker for the tasty shrimp enfolded in transparent outer layer), Shu Mai (large ones, bigger than a walnut with a savory filling of pork, shrimp, mushrooms, steamed) and their Beef Balls.  

Service is quick and I am already nibbling on a puff by the time I hit the door.
author: Miika M.

description:
Cheap dim sum. One of the cheapest places in Chinatown. It's small, cramped, and looks dingy, but it's a good place. Main reason why?

The spareribs over rice. When my mom wants to grab a quick, cheap, filling lunch for 5 (count: FIVE), she orders spareribs over rice. It's good, cheap, and doesn't break the bank. Go go go!
author: Betty T.

description: Stay away! I don't know what everyone is raving about this place is unacceptable in service, taste and hygiene. First the table was dirty we asked twice for the server to wipe it, there was a hair on the plate when the server brought the dishes out, she just brushed it off with her finger and threw the plates at each person around the table. When we asked for hot sauce she grunted and grabbed it off a nearby table and slammed it on ours.  The dim sum itself was beyond disappointing the sui mai was filled with mostly just fat the rice wrap was soaked with water and extra soggy. If you prefer rude service and awful food this place is for you.
author: Grace T.

description: It's fine. It's regular, ordinary dim sum. There's nothing special about it. I would go here to read the paper and eat breakfast over some buns and tea, but not to bring someone to try dim sum.
author: Eric S.

description:
AHH! I LOVEEEEEEE THEIR FOOD. THE PRICES ARE UNBEATABLE. for reals. frickin like... 3-4 bucks for their kickass black bean sparerib rice.. the BEST i've had period... 1-3 for normal dim sum plate... spend like 30 bucks for a family of five... and we always leave happy and full.
all their dim sum is HELLA good, i recommend all of them... to DIE for. holy crap.

howeverrrr. this place is hella janky and dirty and old and disorganized. and service is sort of rude. they might even seat you with some other people in the same table. can you say AWKWARDDD?
but .... overall, still 4 stars because the food is that damn good.
GO THERE. you do not come here for service or atmosphere... you come here for the FOOOOD!
author: Emily C.

description: Love it!  My go-to place for dim sum in SF!  Small, strictly old school, but fine and cheap!  Taro pork balls : my favorite.  Har gow -usually good, although today mine were a little cold. Lots of older folks  enjoying their tea and a little something.  Been going here for 30 years in its various incarnations.  Still good. Not a dim sum palace and service is brusque, but get over it.  The food is worth it.
author: Manya B.

description:
I LOVE dim sum...
I LOVE cheap dim sum even more!!!  

Granted there isn't much to choose from, but the stuff they do have are sooooooooo good...shark fin dim sum and black bean spare ribs over rice...phoenix claws, shrimp & chive dim sum...leaves me & the man feeling stuffed with few leftover pieces for snack later.  The grand total...$12.00.  Yeah, I feel like there is a mistake in the calculation, but when in Chinatown.

Pick up a giant sesame ball on your way out.  Try not to shove the whole thing into your mouth.
author: Je C.

description:
Dont be fooled by the decor and the mean looking workers!

This place has the best black bean spare rib over rice in San Francisco! Hands down. Its only $2.50 and its a good ratio of sauce to meat to rice (to grease)unlike some other places on stockton. It comes in a smaller take out box but it left me really full. Oh and ask for the hot sauce! Its more sweet than burn your tongue off spicy. 

Its a sit down dim sum place where they wheel the food in the carts. The food comes out really slow since theres not that many people working there so I usually order mine to go. FYI they have an english to go menu thats taped to the glass counter so you can just point if they have difficulty understanding you.
author: Stacy L.

description: I walk past Dol Ho on a daily basis- once in the morning, and once at night. I think we all have those mornings where you just can't seem to pull yourself out of bed and don't have time to make yourself a good breakfast. I often have those days, so I've stopped at Dol Ho a few times to pick myself up some cha siu bao (bbq pork buns) for my trek to work. Meh- it's ok. The bun part is a bit too crumbly and the meat could be more substantial. I wouldn't come here otherwise since there are better bakeries just around the corner. But on those late mornings, it will suffice.
author: Christine A.

description: The spare ribs over rice are delish!  Definitely worth coming back here.
author: Robyn F.

description:
[ Food: 3.5/5 ]    [ Ambiance: 3.5/5 ]    [ Services: 3/5 ]
Prices $$ (avg $12/person) 

Down rigth home cooked style dimsum, nothing special, just simple. The chicken rice is the most popular and I belief is their signature dish, it was good and comparable to the way my mom's made with less ginger.

The dim sum portions are huge and being me, I ordered too much for the both of us. So we ended giving some away to couple old ladies... The siu-mai was a little blend and the stuffed eggplant was huge and only lightly seasoned. This is the typical Hong Kong style dim-sum where they keep everything lightly seasoned... so I used a lot of the chili & soy sauce dipping.

There's so many choices and it all depend on if you want to have your dim-sum sitting down or to-go. I was recommended to check out this place by a fellow foodie who swear by it but am sorely dissapointed. Houston's Kim Son @ Fountains is way better!
author: Peter T.

description: This place might be kinda sketchy...but it's fantastic! Don't even let the appearance fool you! The worker ladies are kinda mean...but they're Chinese, so you just get used to it. You'll regret not eating at this place! The little bowls of rice with black bean spareribs are SUPERB! I have never liked these little rice bowls so much in my entire life! AND THEY'RE LIKE SUPER CHEAP. $2.50 A BOWL?! SAY WHAT?! This is all I need at this place. I'm happy. I'm definitely coming back when I visit San Fran again!
author: Joyce L.

description:
Was introduced to Dol Ho by a friend who's been going there for 15 years, maybe longer. I've been there 2 times and I can honestly say I haven't had anything there I didn't either really like or love.
Nothing fancy by way of decor, but is full of Chinatown locals, which says a lot.
Yesterday we stuffed ourselves for around $10 each.
There is a little tea shop across the street you can sample teas at too.
author: Tammy B.

description:
Skkketchy. I'd go for NY dim sum any day over this place.

   First of all, the whole cafeteria-looking restaurant fell silent when three of us walked in. Yes, we know we're Caucasian. Thank you for confirming that. Yes, we do know that in order to be Caucasian we are thereby not Asian. Thanks, again, for making us uncomfortable about that. 

   The food was much more greasy than I've ever had with dim sum dishes.... and the lady serving us was so impatient that she'd just wheel her cart away if we didn't jump at the first option or two. 

    The only reason I liked this place was the little 80-something year old woman we shared a table with, who spoke no English and nearly toppled over with amusement at the fact that we sat with her. We carried on a nobody-speaks-each others' language/ signing conversation for the duration of the meal, and by the time we left I received a hug and a few kisses blown my way from my new Chinese grandmother.
author: Mo S.

description: Rumor has it there is a restaurant where the servers are mean to you. I hate to break to news to you all but unless you are an elderly Asian SF local, the servers will be rude to you. It's part of its charm. Honestly, why would you come here then because the dim sum is AMAZING and the price is so cheap. You will have leftovers unless you have a bottomless pit or am a teenage boy. It is the place to go for out of this world dim sum. Don't expect any fancy schmancy twists, its the classics but done right.
author: Eve C.

description:
I've been here many times and the prices have gone WAY up since the first time I've been here. The portions have shrunk and quality dropped. I would have given this place 4 stars a couple years back. 

If you are non-Chinese, Non-asian, "touristy" looking, you'll get the best service, the deep fried foods will start rolling out one after another. It's cheap, but there are other places that offer more bang for the buck in Chinatown. Not sure why people still come here, even the homemade hot sauce they make don't taste as good as they used to.
author: Felix L.

description: Delicious pork buns! Come for the food, not the service or atmosphere. Little English is spoken here. They seem to prefer you ordering the dim sum you want rather then bringing out items to choose from. I prefer dim sum restaurants with more frequent cart visits and more variety.
author: Chad S.

description: Good experience. Totally no frills. A Minimum Viable Chinese Restaurant (MVCR) definitely. Great dim sum, though some like the shrimp balls were too greasy. The spare ribs on rice were not great but the sauce and the rice were good. Foil wrapped chicken was perfect and the green tea very good.
author: Mikko J.

description:
Dol Ho would be better spelled phonetically as "Daw Ho" in Canto.
It literally means "a lot good" For those of you in Rio Linda, " it's all good".
The setting is real old and tired. I wouldn't call it charming or nostalgic.
Their food is definitely genuine old school and legit. Cheap, but not rock bottom.
It must be pretty close to the bottom because a lot of limited income locals eat here.
I think a lot of the customer base is simply loyalty and unwillingness to change.
"Been coming here for decades and it's my hangout." My family had to wait 20-30 minutes for a table to open up. Once we got it, we settled in and vegged. The place is tourist-friendly. They speak enough English to make the experience passable.  So how's their food? It's slightly above average. It's how they would make em in the village. Don't forget your newspaper. Half the patrons remembered theirs. When the food cart rolls up to your table, grunt alittle and make a hand gesture like you're saying,"Yeah, gimme some of that". We had around 10 dishes. 3 were $3/pop and the rest $2.20. The bill. $35. Hey? wait a minute. the bill shoulda been closer to $25? Did I get ripped off? I don't think so. i think my wife told me the wrong number of dishes. I doubt that they charged us for tea. My wife is real good about checking the bill as all asian wives do. I would of be happier with a $20 tab but we ain't in LA. Yes...there are even cheaper dim sum places in LA if you know where to look. Will I come here again? $35 can buy you a lot of food action in Chinatown. I'm gonna roll my dice on another table.
author: Winston W.

description:
Aww mannnn I was hoping for more chives and stuff for my veggie dumplings. If you like a lot of shrimp in your chive dumplings and what not this place is for you.

I use to come here when I was in Chinese school so I thought it'd be awesome but those were in my eat-an-x-amount-of -meat-cause-im-not-going-to-die-if-I-do days.

I prefer You's dim sum in broadway for my veggie dumpling needs but it's kind of greasy.
author: Margaret S.

description:
I'm still in disbelief that 5 dishes only came to $12. 

I didn't love everything, but it's great hangover food, i must say. Like most authentic dim sum places, there weren't many vegetable dishes (.. actually, none-- the closest was the vegetable dumplings).

It's definitely a great cultural experience. I wish I could order in Chinese like everyone else here.

The very simple decor didn't bother me-- i had read some reviews that said it was dirty, but it wasn't dirty at all. Just a simple little room.
author: Saori E.

description: Great local Dim Sum. Cheap prices and good food. Talked to a local Chinese woman and her tip was if you look into a dim sum place and see a few old guys at a table and each one has their own teapot they are all on their own. And if your an elder single Chinese man you don't waste your time at a so so dim sum place! Great useful tip one that I never would have thought of myself.
author: Steve P.

description:
This place may be the closest that I ever get to the real Kowloon...

Popular with elderly locals, the food here is pretty tasty, even if the decor is lacking...

I made the server smile when I asked for a fork.  That may be the only time she's smiled all month...
author: Nathan W.

description:
This is my favorite spot in the city, but it is not for the faint of heart, and they have many things that are excellent and many things that are mediocre. To be clear: this is "old Chinese man dim sum" as my wife calls it. It is the sort of place that you can imagine the old men sitting around reading their papers would be smoking if it were 15 years ago. 

Don't expect good service or clean tables - that's not why you're here. If you want white tablecloth, go to Yank Sing, though you WILL spend 5-6 times as much as at Dol Ho. 3 people can eat very well here for less than $20

It is VERY popular for lunch. You basically need to seat yourself next to anyone who has a spare seat at the table. The locals/regulars will actually go into the kitchen for their own tea. There are two teas: black and jasmine. The waitstaff (don't speak English, of course) will generally give you jasmine unless you know enough Cantonese...

They do have a "menu" but I suspect it's actually from a different dim sum joint, as I don't think they have half the stuff on it, and the best stuff they have is not on it.

What to order: pork spare-ribs over rice (all the locals eat this), or beef or chicken if you don't want to deal with the bones.  It's the only place I know of in the city to get dried shrimp rice crepe (Xia Mi Chow Fun), though this is not on the menu and difficult to get if you're not a regular or don't speak cantonese. The steamed beef balls are awesome - light and fluffy. The shrimp dumplings and the shrimp & veg dumplings are great - nice thin wrappers. The fried taro cakes are good IF hot, but in general the fried foods are to be avoided if they're not right out of the fryer (they tend to push them around all day...)

Finish up with their steamed custard buns. If you want custard cups or baked goods, you're out of luck. Go right around the corner to Wah Li bakery for their custard cups.

They close for one month of the year to go to China. It's so popular that they are absolutely packed the day they get back!
author: Aaron N.

description: Filthy....dirty tables. Tables were outdated and need to be replaced. Not a pleasant eating environment. Nobody handling the take-out orders. Needs to be on Kitchen Nightmare.
author: Patrick L.

description:
Great prices and good food.

Cleanliness is another matter.  To be honest, I wouldn't bring your "American" friends to Dol Ho.  This is more of a local's joint where they don't care if the waitress wear slippers while they serve food or if there is a thick coat of grease on the walls or there is dust accumulating on the fans mounted on the walls because there is no ventilation.

I would have to say that I like the food here.  They are known for the black bean spear ribs over rice.  You'll see a lot of old timers here enjoying this dish everyday!  

In summary....come here if you have a strong stomach and if you want a "true" village dim sum experience.

Please keep in mind the English Language is limited here.
author: Henry S.

description:
I really like this place.  I love dim sum and i'm not afraid of holes in the wall places not even the ones in China Town.  

The place is small with lots of elderly chiness people who have no problem going to the kitchen to get their own tea.  It's greasy, somewhat dirty (you always have to wipe down your utencils and your table) but the dim sum is good, fresh and very, very cheap.  It's an experience!
author: chloe b.

description: Closed on Wednesdays.  Cash only.  Just order the pork spare ribs and rice - to go!  I heard you can get the spare ribs raw to cook yourself at home but why bother?  Spare ribs and rice is $3 an order.
author: Sandy H.

description: Amazing value.  Great food.  I've been to china/southeast asia a few times, and this definitely compares to what they've got over there
author: Charles C.

description:
Many of the reviews touch on the clientele, the staff's inability to speak English, the decor, and the prices. These reviews are very accurate.  Before I go into my experience with Dol Ho, let me date myself a bit.

When I was a kid, this was the location of Tung Fong. TF was a part of the weekend Chinatown dim sum circuit that included Hong Kong Tea House across the street on Pacific (now another restaurant) and Canton Restaurant on Stockton (now a grocery store, RIP).  Tung Fong had the most amazing foil wrapped chicken, and it was my absolute favorite dish. The closest current reproduction I could find to TF's foil wrapped chicken is the overpriced one offered at Yank Sing.  That is, until today.

Dol Ho is definitely not the same restaurant, and no trace of Tung Fong exists other than the take out dim sum counter to the left of the entrance. The interior is very basic, even canteen-like.

Spare ribs with rice, foil wrapped chicken, steamed beef meatballs, and a pot of tea was $8.70, not including tip. The spare ribs with rice was good and the foil wrapped chicken took me back to my childhood.  I wouldn't order the beef again.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description:
One of my old favorites.  In fact, I afectionately refer to this place as "Old People Dim Sum" due to all the old Cantonese folks that frequent this joint.  And while I've moved on to better dim-sum pastures, I come back here every now and then for the atmosphere and simple tasty selections at decent prices. 

A word of caution.  Despite the large senior crowd, this place is only for the brave.  Meaning, you must be comfortable being stared at if you are not Chinese, and not much English is spoken.  Luckily staring does not bother me, and my child-like Mandarin gets me by.  This place is not for tourists and Caucasians, or anyone else expecting to be pampered.  Learn Chinese and the culture. Don't bring your expectations here.  Just enjoy the food.

Their limited selection means that they make a few things pretty good, including the ha gao, fried taro, and pai gu (pork ribs).  I also like to purchase their homemade chilli dipping sauce. 

Three and a half stars for this old-timers favorite.
author: Gregory C.

description:
Now that Lychee Garden is out of the dim sum trade, Dol Ho is my new default dumpling destination. Seasons change. Big, big thumbs up to their perfect har gow, sui mai and nicely done turnip cake. Shrimp with mixed veggie dumplings are great too. Not a huge fan of their spare ribs unfortunately...just a bit too fatty for my comfort zone. 

No sight of their char sui bao when I was last there so can't compare unfortunately. It's busy, bustling and no frills for sure. I had to ask 3 times for hot mustard, but hey, that's part of the authentic charm.  It's cheap, it's tasty and I'm happy to have it near by. Great for takeout too. I'm gung ho for Dol Ho.
author: wendella a.

description:
I grew up in Chinatown and I barely come to to this place. But when I did, I wish I came here more often. This hole in the wall may seem like nothing on the outside but once you get inside you will see a lot of locals enjoying their dim sum and newspaper.

With my dad I only spent $12 for about 4 plates of food that made me full. It has no menu so you have to just know what to get. the bad thing is you have to know some type of Chinese. With that said this place has amazing dim sum and food. It maybe old and outdated decor but it is not what I'm there for anyways.
author: Ken L.

description:
this barebones eatery on pacific off stockton is full. the take out counter contains the only menu  for the takeout. usually, a lady customer is leaning on the counter and her hand is right over the menu and it's prices.

menu: most dim sum 2.00-2.50
entree:shrimp crepe(2.50) siu mai (4/2.00) char siu bao(3/2,00)

shrimp crepe-small bland crunchy shrimp in a semisoft rice noodle skin. not that  great  but acceptable

siu mai-big pieces with a lot of meat and not much flavor.

char siu bao- fluffy delicate exterior with dried up char siu filling inside. pork filling unacceptable. 

pros
cheap, good value for some items
fast service

cons
-a bitchy saleslady who doesn't listen carefully to orders, even in cantonese, and who scolded a customer for asking about the availability of an item twice. same saleslady doesn't know know to add (i.e. 2 + 2  + 2.50=6.10) i  didn't want to correct her or she would scream at me also.
-msg use is evident.
-parking, you know how it is in frisco!
author: Victor G.

description:
This is a review based on one dish alone: spareribs on rice.  Dol ho serves this up to the old school Chinese in the neighborhood seemingly by the ton.  I didn't see a single table that did not order this and smartly so.  Their spare ribs are tender and the rice is perfectly cooked.  Add in the soy sauce and the ever perfect tin can container and you have an instant classic.  

You are hungry.  You are poor.  Go eat here.
author: Simon L.

description: CHEAP. not particularly great dim sum (although i did love the black bean sparerib rice and some other dish with pork or beef over rice that comes in a metal bowl), but CHEAP. like, eat your fill and pay $7 per person cheap. it's a small place so you may have to wait, and yes, they do seat you with other people if they need to make room, but it's worth it for cheap dim sum! they also have a take out counter if you're so inclined.
author: Clara K.

description: Terrific place for a cheap bite in Chinatown. Somewhat decent dimsum, and the spare ribs rice bowl is seriously the best frickin' deal in town.
author: Guillermo K.

description: Once, as recently as seven years ago, this was my favorite place for dim sum.  Now, 2011, the prices are still as low as you can expect ($3.60 for 8 pieces of shrimp dumplings & pork shumai), but the quality is no longer there.  I did go back a second time just to make sure it wasn't an isolated, bad day.  Would love to hear in the future that things have improved; the loyal locals are still there which was always a big plus.
author: Brian C.

description:
My grandparents have been taking me to this place since I was a wee little boy. The waitresses still remember me after returning from college. My 4 star review is pretty much for their spear ribs and black bean sauce over rice. I say it's the best in the city. If anyone else knows a better place, feel free to message me about it. What makes it even better is that it's only $2.50! 
I find the rest of their menu only mediocre. I agree with everyone else that the place isn't the cleanest, but when I was younger, it use to be even dirtier. I still didn't mind.
author: Michael T.

description:
If you don't like massive-scale dim sum places like Koi Palace, and just want the basics, this is the place.  It's delicious!  And tastes just like my grandmother's cooking.  Interestingly, I found it in "The Slow Food Guide to San Francisco" ... just in case you care about slow food practices  :)  By the way, nothing in this book has failed so far...

BUT...
if you like dim sum places for the fun of seeing tons of steaming and delicious, or weird-looking, or unimaginably deep-fried, or smelly, or unpronouncable dishes (... or, while i'm at it, chicken feet...) whirl around, this might not be the place, as the variety is not as huge and they don't come out as fast.

BUT... 
one time my friend didn't know the name of the thing she wanted, and it wasn't too busy, so the lady in the picture up there (she is awesome) asked my friend to describe it and got it made to order for us!

BUT... 
don't use the bathroom.  It is sometimes said in New York and London that the quality of the bathroom is correlated with the quality of the restaurant.  I think for Chinese and a few other types of restaurants there may be an inverse relationship.  Hasn't been cleaned in a month + no soap = great food.  

BUT... 
on two separate occasions the bill came to $12 for three people!  I'm frugal.  Five stars!
author: Jen X.

description: I came here with 2 friends, and we ordered a couple of basic dim sum to try. The waiter/owner spoke very little English and was a little rude, so it was hard to communicate with her, but overall, we had a great meal. Just don't take the rudeness personally because it seems like their Chinese customers don't mind/care. The price was pretty cheap. If you're on a tight budget, the spareribs would probably fill you up and it's only $3.
author: Pete B.

description:
You certainly can't beat the price or the authenticity factor at Dol Ho. $24 for a stuffed to the rim party of 6- check; no other white people besides our group- check; giant carts of steaming hot fresh dim sum- check.

The atmosphere is not great, but then again it  certainly isn't trying to be. I thought the variety was a bit lacking- especially in the category of buns which was non existent. But what I did eat was fresh, delicious and really on the mark. The service is what you would expect in a joint like this- hurried, non-english speaking and a bit on the rude side.  If you're in the area come to Dol Ho for a quick bite of tasty dirt cheap dim sum- but don't expect to linger.
author: Jess M.

description:
I'm always concerned when we go to a Chinese restaurant and none of the patrons are Asian.  Not a problem at Dol Ho,.in fact, it was quite the reverse which I took as a sign that we had made the right choice.  And what a dim sum feast! Immediately the waitress brought over su mai, hargow and sharkfins.  We followed up with tasty eggplant stuffed with shrimp, egg rolls, and a few other varieties of dumplings.  Given all the food, I expected the bill for 3 to come to $30 of so, but we were all shocked when the total was $14.20 for 3.  

This is definitely a no-frills hidden gem.  But would you have a dim sum restaurant be any other way?  They also do a swift take-out business and you can buy frozen dumplings, wrapped rice and other treats.
author: Rebecca G.

description:
I have been eating here with my mom and dad since I was 11 years old... again I am 28 now... Dol Ho has a special place in my heart... We would park about 3 blocks away, and en route to the restaurant I always had the opportunity to take in the whole Chinatown culture with busy crowds, people who never followed the street signs and continually crossed the streets even with moving traffic, butcher shops with frogs and turtles and boxes for sale, trucks wide open with dead whole pigs ready for delivery, and of course that Chinatown "scent"...

Eating here was always an experience... although it is a hole in the wall where your neighbor is close enough to breathe or cough on your food, the Dim sum is amazing and authentic... A lady in the street once told me that you eat where everyone else eats, or else "they no good"... and she was right, Dol Ho is crowded from opening to closing, but we never really had to wait for seating.

It was usually me, mom, and dad eating there and we'd order a lot of food and only pay around $16.00 and have enough to take home for brother to eat since he didn't wake up for breakfast with us.

Chicken feat, Spareribs over rice, Shrimp Balls, Tripe, Beef Balls, Shu mai, hargow... YUM!
author: Chrysantha C.

description:
OK, we got the name of this place out of a guidebook that said it was cheap if perhaps of questionable cleanliness. And I have to admit, when we walked in, we were the only white people in the place, it was noisy and chaotic, tables hadn't been wiped down, no one offered to serve us, there was nowhere to sit.. and we stood there looking dazed and confused and anxious for a minute or two.

But then this very happy (ok, drunk)  man started waving to us with  a big smile on his face and gesturing wildly to the spots next to him at his table. So we sat down, still nervous, and he began telling us, in limited but enthusiastic English that we had to try the shrimp balls. "it's very good, this place, it's very good, you like!" he said. 

So we started ordering, tentatively, including the spiky fried shrimp balls he recommended. We had some kind of fish concoction on bell peppers, some pork thing.. and truthfully I have no idea what else we were eating, no one could tell us. Btu it was all quite tasty, if greasy, and we filled up fast.

Now, we had been told it was cheap, but nevertheless I could see my dining companion starting to eye the pile of plates uneasily and mentally tally up the bill. So we stopped eating and he went up front to pay-- and came back with an enormous relieved grin on his face.

Our meal of something like five different dishes.. Came to a grand total of $7.80.

He was so pleased he bought us some extra mango custard pies for dessert. Talk about a cheap date! So just remember-- seat yourself, don't bother asking what you're eating and go ahead and order that extra dish: you can afford it!

One last note: Not a place for vegetarians, I think the bell pepper under the fish was the only vegetable I saw while I was there.
author: Sara G.

description:
I think we ordered the wrong things. The dining room was packed, so we just ordered a few of the items in the front case. That was probably where we went wrong. 

The pork dumplings were okay, but hard. The deep fried bun with chicken had a fantastic flavor, but after one the consistency of the bun (really doughy, almost undercooked) got to be too much. The doughy pancake stuffed with some kind of bean was far too sweet and way too doughy for me. 

$4 for 10 pieces of dim sum is great. I just wish I would have liked it more. 

- - -
We ended up wandering down the street and trying dim sum from another place (don't know the name cause there was no sign in English) that we liked much better. There we got a chicken bao and barbeque pork bao for $2 that were awesome and exactly what we were looking for.
author: Katie H.

description:
Best dim sum I've ever had.

They don't really speak english much.

Quite cheap.

Pretty disorganized.
author: Patrick B.

description:
Cheap, good food.  Be open minded.  Try the turnip cakes and the spare ribs on rice.  Try the chickens feet, even!  

Every time I've been there the staff (and other customers) have been helpful in ordering.  Even if the servers don't seem that helpful, they will show you what they've got before you take it.  Just ask, but then if you don't want it shake your head firmly and say no.  Don't smile politely and nod, saying "looks good but no thanks!" Too complicated for their level of English, and they'll think you are ordering what ever it is you're being polite about.  Not a good place for vegetarians or non-pork/shellfish eaters.

The kitchen seems clean to me, and I've not seen the egregious sanitary errors here that I've seen at CERTAIN VIETNAMESE PLACES PEOPLE ON YELP SEEM TO LOVE!!  IF you get my drift.... :)

Eating at Dol Ho is a rich experience.  I'm usually the only white person there.  Occasionally a daring, but confused looking tourist will wander in, but otherwise it's all oldsters enjoying the dim sum they are used to.  That's a good thing.
author: Bruce S.

description:
Best dim sum in the city.  The ladies working the cart there are very friendly.  Be sure to tip them and they will remember you.  And feel free to get your own teapot from the kitchen.  That's how you roll there.

Ridiculously cheap and good.  How can 4 people gorge themselves on $10?!?

This place ain't for clean freaks.
author: Scott W.

description:
I thought that this place was pretty good, but my girlfriend (who knows dim sum much better than me) wasn't all that impressed. Their selection is limited, but it's a fairly small place.

It's definitely a dive. Not very clean and very cramped. They do serve the dim sum from carts despite the cramped space. Don't count on getting your own table. The six of us sat at a table with 2 other diners.

You can't complain about the price. 4 adults and 2 kids ate for under $20.
author: J S.

description:
Ah, my peoples.

Now THIS place is how I envision Chinatown dim sum eating to be.  

The waiters are rude.  Well, it was one lady and she was turning 15 tables like tricks at the Sundowner in Reno.  Sure, she was missing teeth and frankly, she gave us no more attention than your average cat.  

But dagnabit, the food was good.  Sure, it's not your high class Puff Daddy dine on 5th Ave type place, but hey, there were chairs.  There were chairs.  The tables were sticky, but not uncommon for this side of town.  The cups and plates were clean, at least by the looks of it.  But we had a cracked teapot, which I thought was funny.  It was AARP up in there - I think the average age was 89.  And that's including us youngsters pulling the average down.

But wow, they got this one thing on lock.  The steel bowl black black bean short ribs over rice.  It looks a little intimidating - something out of a Terminator movie, but man, one bite and you're in salty swine heaven.  The long noodle with sweet soy sauce and meatballs was very good.  The chicken bun was ok.  The chicken wrapped in foil was like bbq chicken.  The shrimp ball squeezed into the eggplant was ok, but the eggplant was a bit undercooked.  They had the chives dumping in the translucent casing, but it was cold.  Get this, they nuke it.  HHAHAH.   The Chinese matzo ball thing was pretty delicious.  It was the size of a tennis ball.  Three of them.   There were a lot more things they were slanging but I can't remember.  

I think I feel the MSG kickin in.  Wow. Thirsty.  Tired.  But very very satisfied.  It's really a place to get your fill on some Chinese tapas.  It's not a place to host anything, but grab your 3 best eating buddies and go to town.

Oh, and it's SUPER cheap.
author: Isaac L.

description:
This is the type of place where, if you aren't Asian, the record stops, and people stare.

But once you get over that intial few seconds, grab any available seat and wait for the dim sum to start rolling by. Not to worry though--the cart ladies were friendly and patient as they explained and waited for us to choose our dimsum. Same rules of dimsum apply, however: do not order your entire meal from the first cart that rolls by. Look around at what everyone is eating, and wait patiently for that to come around.

The beef balls (or were they pork) and the spareribs were popular here (and tasty). We also had all the dumplings (pretty good), as well as tried chicken feet for the first time (surprisingly decent). For the amount of food we ate (which is a lot), we ended up paying maybe $30? Maybe it was $25 with tip.

There are a ton of dim sum places on this street--a lot are larger and fancier, but this one definitely has spunk. Flourescent lights, metal chairs, and an all Asian crowd means the food must be good.
author: Sabine S.

description:
I first fell in love with the chandeliers at Dol Ho. Honestly, what other place in the city has chandeliers like these? No one. 

That would have been enough. But then, over the course of the last five years and consistent returns, I've slowly and surely become obsessed with the waitress. 

It's all true. If you want something, you're going to need to get it, and, yes, the best way to get tea is yourself, but once you're in, you're in. This is one of the few places in any city I can walk in to and have a smile returned. 

And that's not to mention the food--foil wrapped chicken is probably my favorite here, closely followed by the rice noodle with cilantro and dried shrimp and, well, really everything is pretty amazing.
author: C-Lo J.

description:
Man, I love this place and literally grew up on the food.  I still remember going to chinese school (yes, that exists) on powell and running my ass over here after school or sneaking out during my measly breaktime (whichever came first) to buy my noontime snack.  This place has been here for EVER, at least since I can remember it far back as when I was a wee lass!  You won't find any english speaking dimsum ladies or cashiers here; expect tons of old cranky chinese men with serious loogies and strange hats in the winter, but FEEL the chineseyness ooze out of the cracks of the wall, tiny and always packed, but where else can you get full as hell for 5 bucks?  

Yah, don't expect a whole lot of "service" here because mostly everyone who comes here knows the drill. You flag a server down or grab them lightly by the ear (kidding :D) and say, I want (insert food name here).  Most likely they'll just grunt and point at an empty table or take your order.  I love it!

Man, I miss this place so much...
author: Linda C.

description:
Dirty, noisy, loud and bad service.  Yup!  It's Chinatown!  However, great trad'l dim sum, wonderful on Sundays.  Try to "go to the bathroom" before you get there, and don't use theirs.  

Good to go items and cheap, cheap, cheap!
author: A W.

description:
I would say that my dim sum experience here today was average.

They were very accommodating, even moving people to seat our larger party (though I would most likely be upset if I were on the other end of that deal). 

I had a relatively authentic experience - we were the only white people in the restaurant and the waiters spoke close to no English.

The food was pretty good, particularly the dumplings and rice noodles, but I would say that didn't have a huge variety (no pork buns makes me sad). 

Be prepared to point and have hindered ability to make special requests unless you know the authentic names for things. 

For 6 of us it was $24 which makes it an amazing low cost option.
author: Alicia J.

description:
This is really a hole in the wall dim sum place.  But it is a very good dim sum place.   Very inexpensive.  Their black bean sparerib rice is very popular too. 

I usually come here and get dim sum to go and eat at home.  They don't have a lot of tables and service can be slow if you eat in.  I see people who must be old timers that get their own tea and clean their own tables.  However, trust me when I say their inexpensive dim sum and very good dim sum makes up for it all.
author: Stella C.

description:
It's true, this place is cheap... but regardless of pricing, I will never come here for dimsum again.  My friend raves about it and even brings first timers to dimsum here... but I hate that he does that.  It's not good dimsum, and can leave bad first impressions on people.  The food was fresh, but it doesn't taste the same... I had their siu mai there, and it was nothing but beef.  WHere's the shrimp in it?  It was also very greasy.  True, you can order a crap load of food for $6 between 12 people...  but you're just filling yourself up with crap... Some of their stuff is decent... but you can definitely find better dimsum even at the To-Go places.

I refuse to come here, no matter who's going.
author: Diane L.

description:
Staff was very friendly, and my sister and I had more than enough food for $12. 

There was one time when there was a potsticker type dish that we asked our waitress what it was - her reply was along the lines of "I don't know how to say it in English." So if you're picky, this might not be the place for you. But I enjoyed it.
author: Matt L.

description:
It's the real deal, and my regular Saturday lunch spot.  It's a tiny hole in the wall, kind of shabby, this place seems geared toward locals who are just there to EAT and eat well.

The food is so cheap it's crazy.  And the food is delicious.  I find the service to be perfectly fine. My tea is hot, the food comes out regularly, I'm happy.  

The staff is pretty good about explaining what is what, to the best of their abilities.  This is my favorite cheap eats place in the city.
author: Jamie C.

description:
Scott - Well it was between this place and the New Asia for Dim Sum.  I didnt check what new asia got for reviews on yelp yet, but i took a look at the carts going around and it looked like a bad dim sum restaurant over in the OC called Kim Su.

The seating was pretty ridiculous.. we were waiting to get seated but no one came, so we decided to talk to the person and we were seated with a complete stranger who was reading a newspaper.  There seemed to be one of these guys at every table in the restaurant.  

There were no carts around for about 5 minutes or so then one rolled out with all the dumpling stuffs.  The shui mai was pretty good and the ha cao was really good (Both the shrimp and the vegetable one).  Patty didnt enjoy the chicken feet that much.

After we finished all the dumplings, we waited another 10 minutes or so till the next cart rolled out, this time with all the fried stuffs.  The sesame ball with yellow bean was really good.. it had a nice thickness to it and the bean curd inside wasn't overly sweet and was very smooth.  We also got the fried shrimp ball and the egg rolls.  The egg rolls smelt weird... not something you would normally smell with regular egg rolls.  They tasted alright though.  The shrimp ball was good.  I liked how they made it look kind of like a fireball.  After we finished those dishes, we asked the waiter for the shrimp in rice noodle rolls (I dont know what its called in canto, just viet haha).  The noodles were thick and killed the texture of the dish itself.  We were pretty satisfied in terms of how full we were, but i really wanted a cha shiu bao, but i didnt want to wait for one.

We spent $30 for the whole meal, which isnt bad for 5 people (3 being heavy eaters including me and patty).  It seemed like there were 4 dim sum places at every block in chinatown haha, so i probably wont come back here again.  At least we were joking around with the old guy reading the newspaper.
author: Patty L.

description: Decent. As a visitor to SF where everyone raves about the dim sum, I was expecting more. But, this place does have the old hong kong feel as far as being somewhat dingy, not so well lit, and the perfect place to grab a seat, have a few tins of dumplings, and read the morning paper. These aren't dainty dimsum bites as many of the dumplings are pretty hefty and it's tough to come and eat as a party of 1 or 2 and get to try everything you want (because you'll be full). Most of the filling used in various dishes was very meaty which, just as the hefty portions, can be both a good and a bad thing with dimsum. At the end of the day, I've had better and nothing was particularly memorable.
author: Manesh P.

description:
When people ask me for the quintessential "hole in the wall" place for dim sum, this is it.

The middle-aged women serving you still push around the dim sum in carts.  However, the space is really small (and not the cleanest place), so if there's a large crowd, you may have to wait.  But the wait is well worth it.

It is WAY cheaper than Gold Mountain or New Asia and the food is definitely fresh, made right out from the kitchen.  The ambiance (or lack thereof) definitely plays a big part in making you appreciate the food.  The service isn't that great, but it's authentic Chinatown dim sum; none of that touristy stuff should be found here so ignore the glass cases at the register and sit your butt down for lunch.

Dol Ho is the spot that the locals know, visit, and most importantly, EAT at, but recently, more touristy folks have been coming to try the "pai gwut fan" and the dim sum, so get there a little earlier if you want seats!
author: Connie Z.

description: GREAT Dim Sum ! so far the best Dim sum I have had to date in this city. Love their shrimp dumplings and pork dumplings. Their Steamed BBQ buns are great as well if you get them fresh. Do not expect stellar service..walking in here is like walking into old school Hong Kong. everyone in there was over 50 and Chinese but thats how you now its traditional and good! :)
author: Mike P.

description: Dol Ho is a delightful little hole-in-the-wall dim sum place serving some of the best dumplings and buns I've ever eaten. While the staff doesn't speak a ton of English, they can cook up a storm though. Grab a glass of water, get some yummy buns and pig out on these amazing and cheap dim sum plates.
author: Jason T.

description:
This place is disgusting.   It needs negative stars.

Their offerings made my gf have a sad, betrayed face as she stared at the 8 inedible (purportedly) dim sum dishes in front of her.  

I've always liked dim sum (though mostly in boston chinatown) and my gf grew up on it.  Neither of us have run across something like this before.

As one example: the initially normal sized chicken feet were inflated to godzilla proportions with rancid grease and then allowed to become tepid before being placed in front of us, where they lurked malevolently for the 4 minutes it took for us to summon up the breach of ettiquette to leave the resturant despite doing little besides push the food around and stare silently at each other (and getting stared at silently by the whole resturant while doing so).

Going here was a huge mistake.  We didn't trust yelp again for a long time after that.
author: D E.

description: Do not go here!!!  After reading the reviews, this place seemed worthwhile to grab some cheap dimsum.  It is cheap alright, but you get what you pay for.  We were seated next to the loudest guy ever, screaming in chinese to this other table about how to cook some type of chicken stew.  He literally gave me a migraine.  It was almost 90 degrees outside, but this place is so cheap that they didn't even turn on the stained and dusty revolving fans that they had on the walls.  We asked for ice water and they came back with tepid water straight from the faucet; they have no ice they said.  We had the usual dim sum affair: har gaw(terrible sticky thick wrapping), sui mai (awful chunks of fatty pork), bean curd roll (again fatty chunks of pork rolled in greasy tofu sheet, soaked in grease), chicken feet(just inedible), beef rice roll (gritty thick rice roll with unflavored beef).  We were trying to wait for the notable spare rib bowls, but after waiting 20 minutes for them to cook it, between with the deaf guy next to us screaming and the sweltering heat and atrocious food we already tried, we decided it was just not worth the wait.  We paid our $25 and went on our way; leaving Dol Ho was the best part of the experience.
author: Helene H.

description:
Despite its difficult location - right in the heart of traffic-unfriendly Chinatown - this is a goto dim sum spot in the neighborhood.


 Why?


 It's good, but above all, it's CHEAP.


 If you're in a group of 5 or 6, you can stuff yourself with shrimp dumplings, shark fins, foil-wrapped chicken, shu mai, cha shu bao, or whatever else strikes your fancy for way less than a tenner each, including tea, tax and tip.


 In traditional style, everything is brought up and offered to you on carts - half the fun is trying something random you've never eaten before, the other half is trying to figure out exactly (or vaguely) what it was.


 For the less adventurous, you can simply ask for your staid favorites over and over again, but you have to admit, one of the reasons to go out for dim sum is for a bit of variety.


 Just remember to accept their offer to cut larger items up for your, unless you like getting squirted with hot oil on your first bite
author: Omid T.

description: Spareribs over steamed rice is a must try, so is their house-made chilly sauce, which is not very spicy but delicious!
author: Renee L.

description: I give this small hole in the wall, dim-sum dive restaurant four stars because what you get for the price is very worth it. I find Dol Ho to be honest home-style dim sum. I've been going here for years and typically stand out as the lone gweilo... the mostly Asian clientele is a fascinating socioeconomic mix prime for people watching. The chili sauce on the table is "home-made" and excellent. The steamed rice noodles are very popular with one particular style on nearly every table contains chives and shrimp (wish i knew the name) these must be ordered from the waitress and are not n a menu. The pork-filled sticky rice packages wrapped in tea leaf can be found  in the steamer located at the front window are very tasty. Many regulars order the small rice bowls  topped with meat (Chicken, ribs or steamed meat balls). I've never eaten anything here I did not enjoy.
author: Deno M.

description: One of my favorite dim sum places.  Dul Ho is a little hole in the wall place, and the clientle is mostly Asian.  The staff don't speak much English, but if you aren't daunted by this, go for it and take your pick of delicious, cheap dim sum.  There are jars of some sort of oily garlic concoction at each table, and it is a must-try.
author: Asteridae A.

description:
This is a solid 3 star place.

The often praised black bean spare ribs over rice that comes in a stainless steel bowl was "OK" but not praiseworthy. The portions were small (at least for me).

The dim sum was "OK" too.

A locals place for sure and always crowded but unfortunately that did not mean great tasting food in my experience.
author: John C.

description: Don't get me wrong, the food is incredible, probably the best dim sum I've had in a while. But honestly if you don't speak cantonese, don't bother going. This restaurant exists to serve the old cantonese people in Chinatown, it is always packed and you can hardly get the waitress's attention. They will look at you funny even if you speak mandarin like they don't really welcome you there. The price is great, but I'm sure you can find another restaurant in Chinatown with better service.
author: Jack Z.

description: This is one of my favorite dim sum places to go to in the city. Dim sum is pushed around in carts and served to you. The food is really good here, esp the spare rib rice, shrimp crepe, ha gao, etc. Most of their items are really cheap too, for a dim sum tea house place. The only con is that you may have to share your table with strangers, but for me, once i get my food, i dont even notice the others anymore. Trust me, the awkward table seating is worth oerlooking for the dim sum. Also,  dont be offended by the ladies serving you because that's just how they are. I've gotten used to it.
author: Connie C.

description: delicious dim sum for take out! skip the decor and enjoy the food without the distractions.
author: Sara D.

description: The food is always good.  The service is-well-I don't mind filling my teapot with water from the kitchen.  There is not as much variety as some Dim Sum places-but they are experts at the dishes they serve.  It is so cheap too, which makes it taste better!
author: Gillian F.

description: This a good place for those who like to have good dim sum.  It's cheap and the portion is relatively big, the food is not bad, of course not great either.  The choices is not as much but mostly what you expected.  With this economy, cutting expenses is a way of life.  $12 for 2, what do you expect?  Expect to chase for the cart as they may not go from table by table, plus you may need to refill your own tea pot and not to mention sharing table.  This is not a place to be impressed or pampered but if you do, you should go Yank Sing but expect $50 for 2.
author: P. C.

description: Went there on a packed Saturday morning and really had a blast. The Dim Sum is out of this world. The place looks a tad funky, a mixture of "we don't have money for furniture" and "Red China says Hello". Friends of mine titled it as a "hole in the wall", but the food is awesome. Go there, have tea eat the dumplings and enjoy!
author: Roger W.

description: There are times when authentic is not desirable.  Our visit to Del Ho yesterday is a case in point: the place is dirty, the service is nonexistent, and the patrons bark at one another and the staff alike.  The dim sum was decent, although the pork shui mai was sub-par.  It also cost $9 for two.
author: Nate B.

description: A local favorite for dim sum, but if you're an English speaker don't bother asking questions about what food is what.  *Ridiculously* cheap!
author: Rego S.

description: A lot of old timers come to this place and eat their ribs & rice. It is pretty good here and it is only $2. The service is kind of bad. I do not get how the food system works, sometimes a lady would come out of the kitchen saying "who wants thins rice roll?" and someone would say "bring it here"  the food is pretty good here, but this place needs more tables because I hate sharing tables with people I do not kno!
author: Janet Z.

description: Good dim sum. Don't speak much English there.  Be prepared to split a table with complete strangers.  Inexpensive.
author: jamie j.

description:
Good and cheap.  Parents seem to love the 'pai gwut' w rice and that comes with some kinda soy sauce over it or they leave it on the side. A little too much rice i say and not enough 'pai gwut'!! Usually get the usual dim sum stuff and egg rolls whenever we come to buy stuff from here (the egg rolls taste different each time i get it now, dunno if it depends who's preparing it, they put have/add/subtract stuff inside it) It will fill you and your friends up easily.
I've never eaten at the place, but every time i go buy stuff from here, its usually packed with people.
They messed up the order a few times already.  I order to go and because I order too much and they probably don't remember everything I told them.  But its cool i guess
author: Jason C.

description: Ran across this hole in the wall place last week while visiting San Fran. Cheap, fresh and VERY tasty dim sums. At $2 a portion for steamy (albeit slightly greasy) dimsums who can complain Home-made black bean chili sauce on the table to DIE for. Bought a jar to take home to Nola - my friends are lapping it up. Wish I knew what was in it - I could try and make it at home. Does anyone know what is in it...or can send some heavies over to get the rough recipe?
author: Tracy G.

description: Definitely an experience, and a different kind of place. I might have been less thrilled, but I appreciate new things and more authentic culture. A very simple place, shared tables depending on space, would probably get the best out of it if you knew Cantonese. Seems like an excellent local place for residents to drop by for a bite to eat and a newspaper read. Good tea. Limited array of food, but it'll have most of your standards. Very homemade feel, and pretty good although not the greatest (or just not as much to my taste). Because food circulates without great frequency, it's a nice place to take it slow and easy. I think we got about 8 dishes and tea for 20.
author: Lassie L.

description: How was the food? Hm...I DON'T KNOW! Do you KNOW why I don't know? Because I went in there, with my coworkers, stood there for about 15 minutes, and nobody served us. We wanted to get dim sum to go, and they didn't even help us with our order. Plus, I don't like the fact that you can't see the food before you get it. We went to You's instead, with a big fire in the pit of my tummy. I hear this place has good food, but how would you know if you never even get served? Cheap, good food is one thing, but bad service is a big NO NO.
author: Pika C.

description: A little greasy, but generally good hand-made dim sum. Liked the har gows and deep-fried shrimp balls. Was surprised this place was listed in Lonely Planet, though, as there were no menus and the old ladies just did a show and tell when taking orders.
author: Ethan C.

description:
Super Cheap, really good. I don't know too much about dim sum, but I have eaten it in several SF locations and I'll bet this is one of the more authentic places around. I would avoid looking into the kitchen, but I have yet to get sick. They tend to push some of the more typical stuff at people who don't look like 'native eaters,' but that's par for the course. 

I highly recommend the shu mai (apologes for any misspellings); the steamed pork buns I had were good but we a bit too chewy. (There are better bakeries for that sort of stuff nearby.) But for cost and taste, this is a great weekend morning.
author: Vivek T.

description:
The Worst Dim Sum, Ever!
The steamed items were bound the paper underneath and to the steamers. They had to have been sitting there overnight. The dough is thick and like paste. The flavor of all the steamed dumplings was flat. Any of the dim sum houses around surpass it. Even the frozen dim sum at Ranch 99 easily surpasses it in quality.
Further, the place is filthy.
author: Kent H.

description: Definite hole in the wall. No frills here.  But it's the cheapest  you can find almost anywhere in the city and decent when you need your Dim Sum fix.
author: Jason T.
